content:
Posted: May 22, 2015
												My opinion about the game overall:If you were expecting a funny/punny review then you came to the wrong review. I decided to make an actual helpful/serious review for the game. Let me start off saying this is a really great game and is a real and serious game despite looking like a joke, back when I saw this game in Greenlight I laughed and gave it a vote expecting it to be a game that wouldn't even get to a full release, when it first came out my friend bought it so I went to his place and played it for a few hours, after playing it a few times I decided to buy i. Aas it got more and more updates it got better. A lot of people say the game is hard to play with a keyboard but I disagree, back when I first played the game I didn't have a controller so I played it with a keyboard, after a while, I got a controller, and the only thing that was hard about playing with a controller was that sometimes I got confused with the buttons' names, overall it's better with a controller. Awesome game, they really put a lot of work to it and listened to the community throughout the making of the game.Cons and pros:+Remappable keyboard controls+Changable sensitivity+Graphic options also pretty customizable+Great graphics+Great support from the devlopers of the game in issues you might run into+Achievements-Controls can take time to get used to-New players can sometimes be annoyed by the game's challenge but that's pretty subjectiveGamemodes:Story mode: At the beginning of each level you are presented with some sort of letter about an insane guy who's also the house owner, you finish reading it or skip it and you then spawn as a  piece of bread at the start of the level, at some levels you have extras you can add to yourself like jam and butter which have some side effects. You travel through the level possibly using various objects on the way to eventually get to the toaster or pan or whatever else you want to fry yourself on, in most levels there is more than one way to toast yourself. You get a grade based on your edibility, tastiness and possibly your time but I'm not sure about that, grades are from A++ from F(you only get f if you didn't finish the level). Story mode is overall challenging and my personal favorite. There are 8 levels in the story mode game mode.Bagel Race: In this gamemode you spawn as a bagel in a different spawn than your spawn points at Story Mode, you need to run through the map using 3 and 4 keys(by default assuming you're using the keyboard) and the mouse and pass through checkpoints on the way to the end, you get a grade based on how fast you completed the race. There are 8 levels in the bagel race game mode. You have no edibility in this game mode.Rampage: In this game mode you play as a baguette. In this mode your goal is to cause as much damage as possible to various objects around the level, the more damage you cause the better grade you are gonna get. You have multiplier for everytime you smash a few things at once. You have no edibility in this game mode. Rampage has 8 levels. You have a time limit at this game mode.Cheese hunt: In this game mode you play as a crackbread. In this game mode you spawn as crackbread and start wandering around to find cheese and touch it so it sticks to you, as far as I know there are 5 pieces of cheese in each level. you lose ediblity by falling and/or hitting something too hard. You have no time limit in this game mode. There are 8 levels to Cheese Hunt.Zero G(ravity): In this game mode you play as a slice of bread. This game mode is pretty much the same as the regular gamemode only there isn't gravity and you need to fly around with jets attached to you. I cannot explain the controls to this game mode as they are very complicated to explain, the main difference from the main game mode is that your grade is also based off the amount of fuel you've used up(You have infinite fuel, you use up fuel when you use your jets). You have edibility in this game mode, you lose ediblity when you touch the floor as far as I know. There is no time limit in this game mode. There are 8 levels to Zero G(ravity).I'll edit this to explain about the gamemodes left soon.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								Left for BreadRed Bread RedemptionGranary Theft AutoKnead for SpeedBread RisingBagel-landsProject ZombreadYs-eastCall of Dough-ty … I could go on. I won’t. But I could.******************Due to popular demand Ive decided to add a more ‘wholemeal’ first look review for people who like that sort of thing. The game is essential qwop combined with the floor is lava. You navigate your slice of bread around various obstacles on a quest to get yourself nicely toasted (insert your own joke there).  Encountering dirty items reduces your edibility and therefore your overall score, whilst getting smothered in tasty tasty jam boosts it.The game controls exactly how you would imagine it does. Each corner is assigned a different button which when pressed holds that edge in place apparently regardless of the surface/physics. The mouse or thumb stick flicks the bread around of can be used to nudge it around for precise movements. Practiced or naturally skilled will surely be able to cartwheel their way onto the leaderboards quickly whilst people starting out will ultimately spend more time flailing around like a dying Magicarp. Your main opponent is your own frustration.If the play style is sounding very familiar that’s because it is. Anyone who has already played Surgeon Simulator or Octodad will immediately recognise the pattern of destruction and failure. This means that behind its freshly baked exterior the game is likely to become stale fairly quickly. Like its sister games there is a big potential for fun workshop content but ultimately you cannot judge a game on what could possibly be made by fans later on.It is worth pointing out that it is an early access game, meaning that it is essentially unfinished, although this game does feel a lot more complete than most. It is very much playable with the exception of a few minor bugs. Enabling the gif record mode makes the game basically unplayable and the music always seems to be coming out of a random corner of the room. I think overall most people will have already made a decision about this game, and whatever your thoughts they are probably correct. It’s ultimately a casual iPad-destined meme-maker but it clean fun and will give most people a few laughs for less than the price of an average cinema ticket. If flinging a slice of bread around for a few hours is the sort of thing that will brighten your day, then this is probably for you.

number of helpful: 1,016 of 1,241 people (82%) found this review helpful489 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								I started the day as a slice of bread. Not the end piece, because no one likes the end piece. No, I was the second slice in. I emerged from my loaf in glorious fashion, spreading my crumbs all over as I flew from what I once called home. This was the start of my journey. I emerged in to a world of culinary decadence. To my left was Mt. Butter, and to my right was Jelly Valley. There were so many places to see, so many things to do. Life had finally begun.I began my voyage to Toaster Kingdom by first heading for Mt. Butter. It was always a dream of mine to stand-atop the hills on Mt. Butter, and I did just that. I paraded to the top in mere seconds, only to slide down Mt. Butter and splash right in to Jelly Valley. It was like a slip-n-slide of deliciousness.I emerged from Jelly Valley covered from bread to toe, only to come to the edge of the world. I could see it all from here; the vast landscapes of Breadland, the hills of Crumbilina, but most of all, I could see Toaster Kingdom, and I knew my journey was far from over.In a moment of serenity, I took a giant leap of faith, and I floated through space and time, in an absolute moment of glory. I didn't know what was waiting for me below, but I knew this was what had to be done.Falling for what seemed an eternity, I thought this to be the end. Just then, something emerges below me, and I land softly on to a giant looking board with wheels. My savior.I thanked it for saving me, and we bonded very quickly. It turns out, we are both heading to the same destination, and he agrees to let me travel on him. I hold on tight, and off we go. We travel through canyons, wastelands, hell, we even traveled through large ravines. We're almost there. We arrive at the Counter-Top Haven. The final stop before Toaster Kingdom. Just when we are in-reach of the Toaster Kingdom, my new friend informs me that he can go no further, for he is not capable of climbing. He entrusts me with a gift for King Toaster, a serum of sorts. He called it Maple Syrup. I am clueless what it would be used for, after-all the King is french. I don't understand what he would possibly do with such a thing. Nevertheless, I say thank you for everything, as a tear of jelly starts rolling down my face, and I start my ascent to reach the top of Counter-Top Haven.It's a rough climb. It takes me about a minute or two, as I seem to be slipping and sliding all over the cliffs and peaks of this place. Maybe it's the jelly, maybe it's the butter, but all's I know is that I must persevere. I must make it to Toaster Kingdom.I finally reach the top of Counter-Top Haven, and Toaster Kingdom and the Toaster King are in my line of sight. I flop towards them as fast as my nimble body can take me, battered and buttered and bruised. I reach the entrance to Toaster Kingdom. I can feel it now. I'm almost there. I only have to climb once more and I will have completed my first voyage.With all the strength I can muster, I grip tightly on to the walls of Toaster Kingdom. I manage to hoist myself a-top this beautiful landscape. I'm here. I made it. The Toaster King is in sight. I just have to decend to the throne room, and I will have fulfilled my purpose in life.Just as I am readying myself to decend towards the king, a gust of wind blows me off of the top of the kingdom. Down I fly, past Counter-Top Haven. Below I go, to the ends of the earth. No one to save me this time. I fall. I fall. I land in the dirt. Ruined.I wither and die.10 / 10. Would play again.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								Rather tricky, but very fun. You use 1,2,3,4 to 'grab' onto a surface, then you swing yourself to move! The goal is to get to the toaster on the other side of the room, and to toast yourself. It's definitely not as simple as it sounds, though!It's a fantastic game for its price. :>EDIT 12/04/14: I didn't expect this review to get so much attention, geez. x3A lot of people seem to be under the impression that it's free-play, and that there's no real goal or penalities, etc. I'll clear that up for you.There's no sandbox mode yet. The only real limitation you have, is not touching the floor. If you do so, it'll drain your 'health bar'.  There are a couple of different levels. Even if you manage to complete them all, the replay value is high, as there's multiple ways to complete each level! Despite being early access, this game feels perfectly complete! It's fun to play in 'bursts'. :>*some li'l genuis was complaining about everyones' playtime on it. It literally just came out yesterday (12/13), dork.

												Warning: Contains GlutenIn all reality I've actually had a lot of fun with this so far and I havent rated higher than an F. Playing with a controller as well though, I imagine the keyboard and mouse method is even more irritating.*Edit*I made it to day 3 and no longer only get F's. The amount of creativity the second level requires is enough to be worth $10. This isn't an A  to B type puzzle game. You not only have to figure out what's going to be your toaster, but how you're going to get there and make it capable of toasting.I've only gotten to try day 3 once so far but the fact the walls are dirty and I once again have no idea what is going to toast my bread adds a whole nother level of puzzle solving I was not expecting from such an outlandish game.Even after passing day 1 multiple times and day 2 once I still haven't managed to make my toast "tastey" though. I've only passed on the fact that I toasted bread without completely covering it in♥♥♥♥♥♥Definitely recommended and I haven't succesfully finished 5%.12 Grain/10

number of helpful: 1,122 of 1,614 people (70%) found this review helpful20 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								Serious Review:Do I Recommend this game?Yes and No.The game is fun, and i love and adore physics based games.I Am Bread is a game where you play as a bread, trying to get through it's day to get toasted.However you must not touch the ground/floor.  That will kill the edibility of the bread.However trying to steer this bread or moving it it's extremly tedious... i HATE the controll sceme (I tried both Keyboard and Gamepad (xbox controller)  It's very hard and takes tons of time to get used with the controls.I spend over 18-25 minutes on the first level... trying to get this bread toasted.  it's very hard but managedable with a bit of cursing with tears in my eyes. the second level is even worse and i don't even want think about the rest.Then again i see how no other control sceme would work for this game.What i like:* Grapichs and physics* Fun to break stuff and climb onto things.What i hate:* How you control the bread...* How there was NOT any free roam/free play from the start where you can just mess around without having to worry about the floor.So there you have it.If they where kind enough to add a free roam to the game from the start where you could have a little fun i would be very pleased and give it a YES.But it seems you have to spend hours on trying to get toased and move on the next day, no idea if they will reward you with a free roam function.This is an early review of the game and i might change it later.For now, i do not recommend this game. to tedious.EDIT:I am not a hater of the game, as many comments below state.I know these type of games and i'm very femiliar with the Surgon simulator which is also very hard on the controlls.The idea is brilliant and the concept is fun and adoring, and i'm a working male who plays video games in my spare time and i'm quite the good player on most games, and i'm not "bad" just because i can't get passed day two.  It's early access and they want to listens to people's good and bad reports of it.I'm just saying the game show no remorse for a simple mistake. You fall, you die. Restart and spend another 25-30 minutes getting through the level. Don't take my word for it, read other people's negative reviews, they will state the same.People who says "I'm a bread, got jelly on me and fell face down. 12/10" is a part of this new "funny steam review" trend and don't take the game all to seriosly.  Thanks to people who actually cared for my review!

content:
Posted: December 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								Five days at Breaddy's is truly a work of art in the horror-simulation games department. The game puts you in the place of a lone slice of bread, lost in a large house with no idea of how he got there or how to get out. It perfectly represents all of the horrors bread goes through on a daily basis, such as but no limited to:-Climbing on the wall-Sticking to a box of chips-Getting stuck in the aforementioned box of chips-Riding on a skateboard-Touching the floor-Playing Jenga-Falling from the top of a refridgerator into a sink-Touching the floor-Forgetting which sides LT and RT are on-Doing cartwheels-and touching the floor.This game has no jumpscares, but has enough tension to make you go crazy. You'll constantly be thinking things like "OH GOD I'M STUCK ON THE FLOOR! WHY CAN'T I STICK TO THE SKATEBOARD!?! LET ME ON THE SKATEBOOAAAARD!!!!" and feeling true terror nearly all the time.I give it a Potato out of Rye. Really a must play.Are you ready for Breaddy?

number of helpful: 264 of 377 people (70%) found this review helpful14 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								EDIT: You only need look at the top reviews for this game to realize why you should stay away. Almost every one of them is nothing but stupid bread related puns. Don't trust the user rating.Seems like it's just another "zany" game now that the goat simulator hype has died down.People who enjoy "teh randumbs" will probably enjoy this game, but I didn't personally enjoy this title after going through the first level.The game is quite simple. You try to guide a piece of bread across the room to a toaster and toast yourself inside of it. while trying to keep your "freshness" as high as possible without touching things like trails of ants or the floor..However, in my opinion, the physics are just awful. I would much rather the bread have QWOP's physics system than the system it has now. A problem I constantly run into is the bread not turning the right way, not properly turning, or just not turning at all.All in all, it may seem like a good purchase just because of how out there the game is, but you'll probably regret it after putting it down about 10 minutes later.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								tl;dr - Use the money you'd spend on this game to buy an actual loaf of bread -- you'll have more fun with that._____I'd like to preface this review by saying that, truly, I was actually looking forward to this game.  It seemed quirky, sandbox-y, and hopefully enjoyable, and the reviews seemed to be overall positive.  It couldn't all have been just people rating it highly, just because you're playing as bread, right?  This had to be actually fun!  However, having now given this game a try, I can say that it doesn't live up to the hype at all.  First, I should state, from the trailers, it would seem like the game takes place in a sandbox-type game style.  Run around, cover yourself in crud, do stupid stuff, etc.  Tons of fun, right?  Well, if you're looking for that kind of gameplay, you've come to the wrong place, currently.  Perhaps when the game is more developed, there will be a free-play mode, but currently, there is only an objective mode, wherein you must make it from one side of the kitchen to the other, and toast yourself.  Still sounds fun, right?  Now, I imagine you may be sitting there going, "At least you can cover yourself in all sorts of stuff!"  Except, you can't, or your edibility bar hits zero and you get a game-over.  "Well, I can still climb all over the place, and swing from shelf to shelf like some gluten-based Tarzan, right?"  Well, bad news, you've only got a limited grip gauge that very quickly depletes, and you need to let it recharge again before you can grab anything, once it runs out.  Anddd when you hit the floor, your edibility quickly drops, as well.  I'm sure that, as it's early access, some of these issues will probably be addressed, but at this point, the trailers look much better than the game is.Still, you know what?  That could still be a fun, challenging game.  Could be.  That is, if not for what me be perhaps the worst problem with this game: the contols are just awful.  And no, I don't mean like Surgeon Simulator's "haha this is hilarious" awful, I mean "why is the mouse suddenly inverted?  It didn't move like this before.  Why is it not responding to my movements?!" awful.  Seemingly at random, the game decides that you're now pulling back when you're pushing forward, swinging left when pulling right, etc., and then, at the drop of a hat, decides to go back to normal again.  Usually while you're climbing the walls with your quickly depleting grip gauge, or trying to finagle your way into the toaster slot, resulting in you either falling to the floor (at which point, the process repeats until your health edibility bar hits zero) or you flinging the toaster down to the floor, where toasting is not really an option (again, inevitably resulting in the edibility gauge hitting zero, but even more heartbreaking is victory is wrested from your fingers.  Er... Crust?).  If these controls didn't decide at random not to work, perhaps I could have had fun.  Perhaps this could have been a worthwhile game.  However, as it stands, the game is not challenging, it is just downright frustrating, and it is NOT worth your money.  Wait for them to improve the handling (if they ever do).

content:
Posted: November 18, 2015
												[review remade as of 12/20/16]So you know how you make toast in the morning? Wouldn't it be nice if it made itself?Oh wait, no, it wouldn't, because it would make a mess all over your house because everyone knows bread is the most stupid in the exact circumstance where it has no idea what is a good established way of walking, because it can only move itself based on its corners.I Am Bread is a game where you are bread, a cold, plain bread, so you must go to the toaster / microwave / heater / lawnmower with faulty circuits causing it to overheat for warmth, as most beings need to be warm to live. Also, being toast is one of your priorities that is solved by being warm. Plus, being rated as a delicious, A+ quality toast is important to bread society and as such you must be delicious in order to come out on top of society. However, there are several obstacles in the way of you flopping yourself into that toaster! Let's list them. Controls! You can only move by grabbing objects or terrain with the corners of your bread and pulling yourself up. If you mess up your wall climb, you may end up on the floor. Flooring! Everyone knows the floor is dirty, and potentially lava in some circumstances. Dirt usually contains bacteria, which are bad because they may eat you before you are toasted, and your primary life goal is to be toasted, and your secondary goal is to be delicious, so they stand in the way of your life goals.  Ants! Ants are devils. They will rip you up into crumbs and feed you to their queen. It is not optimal to be around ants, as they do not rate bread and therefore, you get the default score, 0.* Water! Soggy bread is not delicious bread. Also, sometimes, water contains bacteria. (see bullet point on flooring) Etc.However, these are not reasons to be discouraged! Many things will help you on your way. Butter makes you more delicious, and so does jam. Also there's a rocket in the first level. It helps I guess. But the goal of the game is to be at least edible and at most, delicious. Do you think that sounds fun? Well, I thought this game was fun, so you have one person out of the many hundreds of people who have played this game's opinion, which is yeah go buy it right now or maybe later or I don't know, just when you have the time.

number of helpful: 33 of 46 people (72%) found this review helpful13 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												I wasn't here for the trip through early access, but coming into the launch version blind, my experience was one of endearment, gradually eclipsed by a roaring frustration. It's a lovely novel concept, the story (yes, there is one) is pretty good, and the level design ranges from open and flexible to linear and ♥♥♥♥ WHOEVER MADE THIS. Mercifully, there is a Super Guide equivalent to let you get through any level at the expense of a forced E rank, although even with that in place you can still be hard pressed to figure out how to toast yourself.I realize that the game is fumblecore at its heart, but it often seems to demand just a bit too much for what you can feasibly do with its unique blend of A) the controls, B) the physics, and C) the camera. The controls in and of themselves are generally manageable, but when attempting to swing like Bread Tarzan across a string of 6 or so sunflowers and the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ cocking things are just flailing about as though in a typhoon because of arbitrary WACKY physics, the game just starts to fall apart. If you manage to smash open a jam jar to coat yourself, you can spend a full couple of minutes wrestling with all of the broken glass trying to actually make contact with the jam -- and once coated it can actually make movement much more challenging, to the point that you'll be unable to detach from a surface until you've swiveled the camera to an angle where the controls feel like cooperating, assuming the camera also cooperates and doesn't get stuck inside a wall pointing at the ceiling. When levels last upwards of 10 minutes and have no checkpoints, getting dicked to death by the camera and/or how it interacts with the controls is not a fun experience. The epilogue took me 5 tries alone; once because it was my fault, three times in a row because the physics made my bread clip into the car and spaz out, the third time ending with me launching into space at infinite velocity. There's only a handful of levels in total but a few different modes to play them in and a standing possibility of more post-release content for free and/or as DLC. All in all I enjoyed it, but the physics and camera still definitely need work, and due to the prolonged format of the levels as compared to Surgeon Simulator, it's just a much more frustrating experience as a whole.As a final caveat, none of the achievements seem to work yet either.

number of helpful: 21 of 23 people (91%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								It's not often you find a game where the concept, gameplay, and story are all original, and it's even rarer to find one that executes all of the above in an engaging and entertaining way, but I Am Bread manages it with panache. As the game opens, you find yourself as the titular slice of bread in a typical kitchen with one straightforward goal: to become toast. There's no tutorial and no on-screen hints to guide your progress, but a little bit of exploration will make the control scheme clear - you can grab with any combination of corners at once, and nudge, flip or fling yourself toward furniture or objects scattered about the room.Sometimes the physics of interactive objects gets a little wonky; grabbing onto an object as it topples may sometimes hurl you in an unexpected direction, but the simulation is pretty solid otherwise. Hazardous elements of the environment are left for the player to discover; surfaces or objects that decrease the bread's "ediblility", hurting your score and eventually causing you to fail the level.Succeeding at becoming toast unlocks a new room and a little more of the backstory, hinting at a larger meaning beyond finding a way to brown oneself. The novelty of the concept and the control scheme make a simple game very enjoyable and eminently replayable.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2015
												This game is amazing!  The main story is a fully immersive action, adventure, 3D platformer, roleplaying puzzle game with unexpectedly dark twists in the story.  It is truly an emotional roller coaster as you hang on for dear life, inches away from safety, flinging yourself upward with the little strength you have left in a desperation, only to fall to a painful death, alone, far from loaf of your family, on the cold hard floor.  Then you try again, and again, as frustration and you question whether it is even possible to reach you goal is this cruel world.  The feeling of accomplishment after finally succeeding makes it all worth it.  You learn, if a piece of bread can overcome all the odds and become toast, you might have a chance at succeeding in life too, if you stop playing this addicting game and go live it.  You also learn that alcohol compounds psychological issues.There is more to this bread simulator than the main story.  I was pleasantly surprised to unlock a thrilling time-trial racing simulator, a very realistic and somewhat more calming space exploration simulator, a destroy everything simulator, and even an annoying fetch-quest simulator.  They even added a free Star Wars parody game for May the 4th.  In short this game is much more than meets the eye.  It is extremely difficult and fun.  10/10

number of helpful: 26 of 35 people (74%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 11, 2016
												There's challenging gameplay, there's unforgiving difficulty, and there's broken clumsy controls. The challenge in I am Bread doesn't come from the gameplay, or the missions, or the success conditions, but instead from fighting with the controller to do what you want it to do. If the player fails it should be due to his or her actions, not because the game decides to work against their inputs.The humour of the game wears off quickly and it isn't enough to carry the frustration that comes from the core gameplay. Rampage mode is a nice option and serves as pure catharsis. I would actually be more interested in playing a fully-fleshed out Katamari Damacy style game with the rampage mechanics.Overall, probably worth a try but I wouldn't pay full sticker price.

number of helpful: 97 of 161 people (60%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								To summarise my opinion on this game, the learning curve is like trying to climb an overhanging cliff, both literally and metaphorically.There isn't much really to say about it, the controls are almost unusable;, they worked in Surgeon Simulator where you where the camera was always the same, however in this the camera has a variable orientation, and so relying on the direction of the bread which isn't easily distinguishable when you're stuck on something of the horribly balanced first level or fell onto the floor because you don't want to move the camera around to see if the gap between the fridge and the cubbard is too big to gap (protip: the cubbard receeds so far in you cannot scale it whatsoever, avoid at all costs) and while you can get used to the controls, you do so in the manner someone who recently was disabled learns to use the toilet while in a wheelchair. I'd reccomend changing it so that the arrow keys move in relation to where the camera is facing, and WASD are fixatedly assigned to a corner, and overlap each other the further away they are from the camera.Also, the camera has the sensetivity of my rib cage being perforrated by the fingers of someone with anorexia. Even the slightest movement will cause it to jerk 180, and if you were grabbing onto something good luck getting where you were planning on going before you fall to the floor with the (at least what I interpreted) message "♥♥♥♥ you thats what you get for trying to rotate the camera".Also, the trailer is very misleading. While it advertises a simple game that tells the tale of a slice of bread on its quest to become toasted, when you get in game you get a happy upbeat song to the tune of a level whose traversability resembles that of a poorly made game with graphics that don't match the lacking quality of the level. The Jenga blocks are evil and you will get stuck on them because you're a loaf of bread with a big area and those jenga blocks don't leave much room on either side for you to pass.You are virtually immobile when not grabbing onto something, and I think that is just stupid. Grabbing should be a method to assist you to get from A to B, not be the only way to do it. Just have the bread flip and timble according to what edges/surfaces are touching what and in what direction the bread is travelling.Finally, make getting past the fridge easier. If you try to go up it you'll run out of grip before you realise there is no space at the top to climb over, and if you try to go in front of it you'll realise that the cubbard handles protrude so much that the stale bread you represent cannot bend the majority of its body mass around the corner of a fridge ever so slightly to grip the recessed area of the cubbard, which if you didn't know is basically everything except the handles.I said it once and I will say it again, stay away from the cubbard because it will ♥♥♥♥ you up.First level needs some SERIOUS rebalancing, music is too upbeat, camera is on steroine and the controls are aparaplegic. Those problems need to be fixed fast, because thats not how you add challenge to a game, thats how you make it unplayable, a hugely unappealing game, and a waste of €8.

content:

Early Access Review
								Let me start off by telling you what 'I am Bread' is. 'I am Bread' is one of the most moronic things ever created. It's a stupid little game where you play as a piece of bread and you have to toast yourself. That's it. The controls are absolutely terrible and the game is extremely difficult. This game is in very single way shape and form a piece of garbage. Which is exactly why you should buy it. You get to play as bread. If that doesn't appeal to you, then you're a sick and disgusting human being. As for the game being unplayably hard, that's the whole point of the game. No one said being a piece of bread was easy. No one really ever said it was hard, either, but they never said it was easy. This game is exactly what it was made to be. A stupid yet challenging game about being a damn slice of bread. I paid $8.49 to be a piece of bread. I'd pay it again if I could, it's that good. If you're the kind of person that thinks being a slice of bread would be fun, buy this game right now. If you're not that kind of person, then go kick puppies into a river or do whatever else it is that you party-poopers do."12/10 would bread again." John C. Calhoun, circa 1441 BC

								This game is great. Even though there are 4 levels in the game right now, I have fun playing them over again. (First level is the best :D). There are a lot of comments about how the controls aren't very good. They are 1, 2, 3, and 4 for gripping, and q,w,e, and r for locking the grip. To be honest, I couldn't see any other way for the controls to work anyways.Just some ideas that the devs could add are:co-op sandwich modeVS. mode (see who can get toasted with the highest quality)More stuff to smear in (jelly and butter are the examples in the game)A few more Easter Eggs just for the kicks. :)Overall I would give I am Bread a serious review of 9.5/10.Good job Bossa studios. This game has given me the inspiration to eat more and more bread.

number of helpful: 21 of 28 people (75%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 19, 2016
												I am Bread is a third Steam game by Bossa Studios who are known thanks to their crazy Surgeon Simulator. If you've already seen (or played) the game, you know it challenges players by having difficult controls that makes it frustrating but also hilarious to play. In this case, they did it in pretty similar way, with important difference: You will be in control of a slice of bread that wants to get toasted. (A great potential friend for toaster from Red Dwarf!)Yes, it's a weird physics simulation game where you are trying to move bread towards a source of heat. Controls revolves around four buttons - a button for each bread's corner that makes it sticky. If you are now thinking about the movement, you have probably already thought out that all the movement is done by swinging and flinging on those stickied bread corners.I can't say it would be unexpected after Surgeon Simulator, but it's still important to say that I am Bread is a difficult game. It has a high level of difficulty, you'll be raging a lot because while you'll be trying to get to get toasted (by toaster or table lamp, for example), you'll also have to dodge all dirty and wet areas and objects. Don't even think about touching ground! It's like the floor is lava, it makes you taste bad which leads up to the game over screen. And one more thing, you have limited "sticky timer". You can hold on some place swinging just for a moment, then you have to lay somewhere to regain your energy for being sticky.While it's definitely a great game for skilled speedrunners, don't expect to get into it easily, you'll need a lot of practice to beat levels without getting dirty. Good thing is that the developers knew how begineers will suck at it, so after two times you lose a level, you'll get an option to remove the sticky timer and edibility meter (edibility is reduced by getting dirty).The main story mode offers a classic level list with funny short story, delivered via medical reports, about a man who gets crazy because he thinks that a slice of bread is destryoing everything in his house. But there's more! There's also a cheese hunt, bagel race (probably the easiest game mode), rampage (where you have to destroy everything with baguette), zero-g (to make you even more frustrated), and free play mode.It's worth mentioning that developers made a lot of free content for I am Bread later after release - Team Fortress 2 bread level, Goat Simulator mode (just change bread for goat) and Starch Wars mode, which is a kind of weird 3D space shooter with laser bread (referencing Star Wars, of course). Even if it's been done with the idea of cross brand marketing, I really appreciate that those updates came up for free!The game supports keyboard and mouse or gamepad controls. While other players had problems with controllers, I played with Xbox 360 controller without any problem, haven't seen any lag through my gameplay sessions.Conclusion:I am Bread is a perfect game for those who want something silly but difficult. It requires a lot of practice to get good at it, so depending on your perseverance, it can offer you many hours of entertainment and huge self-satisfaction in the end... or a lot of frustration. So it depends on your temper, but it's definitely worth buying.

content:

Early Access Review
								This game is basically "the floor is lava", except you are a sentient piece of bread whose quest is to become toast. Although the first level seems simple, there are multiple ways to achieve your goal, all with varying difficulty. You have to maintain your edibility level otherwise it's game over, because who the ♥♥♥♥ wants to eat a piece of toast covered in dirt and ants? You can also make yourself more delicious, if you so desire. Past the first level, the ways to become toast aren't exactly the most obvious, so you will spend time exploring the room and finding creative ways to reach toasty nirvana.The controls can be tricky to handle, and that's half the fun.. and all of the frustration. Although you can use your keyboard, using a controller is much simpler (assuming you can discern your left and right, otherwise it can be more frustrating). Overall, it's a stupidly fun game. Breadkin rejoice, your time to shine has come.

number of helpful: 13 of 15 people (87%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 7, 2016
												Like all wacky physics simulator games it's cute to play for a bit but ultimatly more frustrating than it's worth. And not frustrating in the makes-you-want-to-beat-it-more sense, but in the I-don't-understand-why-that-just-happened sense. The controls aren't meerly challenging as they are unpredictable. It's often difficult to tell what pressing forward will cause the bread to do; sometimes flopping one way or the other. The degree of motion is also somewhat confusing. Throwing the stick in a direction  can send the bread in a flying leap or have it just limply flop over. This sounds minor, until you factor in rediculous time limits and surfaces that can rapidly drain your health from a momentary touch. The physics engine can't behave itself (check the community page, it's like 60% gifs of the physics bugging out). Which again, is cute to see happen, but when you've spent 5 minutes making your way across a level, only to be thrown across the room by a bug, it quickly turns from cute to controller snapping frustrating. If you can pick it up for a couple of bucks the wackiness is certainly charming and distracting, but ultimatly the frustrating lack of agency in the game play will probably have you giving up long before you've explored most of the content.

Early Access Review
								This game is an emotional roller coaster. no no not just one but 2 emotional rollercoasters on the same track that you think for sure will hit eachother like in rollercoaster tycoon, but never seem to because they are real things and in real life that doesnt happen quite as often as videogames try to make you believe. The life of A Bread is a difficult one, full of the daily struggles that we all face. From avoding ants to  climbing up the counter, the circle of life for our pal bread is a microcosm for the world. I guess you can say that we are all like bread or perhaps the bread was just inside us all along. I find comfort in that. anyway if you thought day 1 was hard, i assure you day 2 is a nightmare with a big fluffy difference... a rug. Spider bread spider bread friendly neiborhood spider bread.

number of helpful: 10 of 11 people (91%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 8, 2016
												Not a game for everyone, lets just get that out of the way. But I do suspect Dark Souls players, such as myself, are in the right mind-set to understand I Am Bread, and enjoy it. Once I got the right idea, it became addictive and, amazingly, rather meditative.In terms of gameplay it's slow and takes loads precission and patience. If you're expecting run-and-gun instant satisfaction, look elsewhere, this is not a CoD generation experience. Make your way through a level at a snails pace, enjoying the journey, however, and victory is incredibly rewarding. Yes, the controls take getting used to, but it honestly didn't take as long as I thought to have my bread doing air-flips.One major issue that can't be ignored; the camera is not your friend. And in a game requiring such concentration and precission, that can be a right pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ (Likewise with Dark Souls.)All in all, I tip my hat to the developers for originality, incredible detail, and amazing sound design. (The music gets repetitive quick, but the sound of physical objects is outstadning.)

number of helpful: 14 of 18 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								TL;DR at bottom After Level one--------------------so far the game seems like a challenging one, and with my desire for challenge, this game was a good purchase. The controls are filled with freedom, I can put all sorts of muscle memory into these eight keys, allowing for quick, situation based reactions. I have just unlocked the second level but can not yet locate the toaster, I have scouted one half of the room, and soon I will check out the other. I am Bread has not yet gone stale, and I feel I could enjoy it for flours on end. It is enjoyable for me not only because of the challenge, but there is the fun appeal of being a bread, I'm not sure why but I feel as though I have always wanted to play as bread in a game. Luckily this isn't any sort of fake game like goat simulator, and I am excited to see what kinds of updates that could be in the future. The resolution settings are customizable like most games in case if the bread starts to look too grainy, and if you just barley make it to the toaster, but hit the ground, you have to wait until the next growing season.by playing this game I have reaped the rewards of being entertained and have recieved a hunger for bread. After level two--------------------Of course, I should've known, level two's toaster is  actually not a toaster. Apparently the game has some secrets up it's sleeve, hopefully it won't stump me for long next time. this game is just a sheaf of fun. On top of the controls, puzzles! Although maybe I was just too mesmerized by the bread to notice what wasn't intended to be a puzzle. Even if this game doesn't become the best or come out fully cooked, it plows the way for more innovative game designs. I thought I would do a short paragraph per level but realized I'd probably best slice the bread and cut to the chase. Sadly I could not part with all these puns.PROShardGood controls (so much muscle memory to be had)Sentient Breadinsane homeownerBushels of varietyCONSno multiplayer TL;DR If you like a hard game, and need some muscle memory fun, this is your game.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								At the moment, I can not recommend this game.  The controls are extremely confusing and frustrating.  Only once have I been able to get to the countertop in the first stage, and it was through sheer luck that I did it.The major problem I have is that climbing (or navigating at all) is not as simple as "point in the direction you want to go".  Numerous times, while wishing to scale the walls, I would press "up" on the controller (or keyboard, which is a bigger nightmare to use), and my bread would go down.  I would then press down, and my bread would move about half way, and be perpendicular to the wall.  Then, instead of pressing "up" at this point, I would have to rotate the stick 180 degrees around, and finally I could move forward.The game seems fun, but the control is extremely complex.  For a game like QWOP, which was a silly Flash game with no real purpose, this control scheme would be fine.  But this game seems to have multiple levels, each with varying levels of difficulty.  It's because of the control alone, and I can't recommend this game.At the very least, there should be an option to add in a simplified control, or to remap buttons.  Perhaps a less strict grip meter?  Make the floor not eat away at your edibility by just being stationary, but when you move?I understand this game is in early access, so I'm not being overly critical of it.  I do hope these "problems" are fixed though.  If they remain, I may not be able to play this game as I simply don't have the mental dexterity to handle it.

number of helpful: 8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 10, 2015
												This is more than just a joke game.  This is a masterpiece well worth your time.CONTROLS:First of all, personally I like the control system.  For the main story mode hold down a button to select a bread corner, then move it in the direction you want it to go.  Sure there is a short learning curve, but I find climbing and navigating the world with these kinds of control schemes very enjoyable.  The gifs you will find posted by the master players on the community hub are a joy to behold.  Don't be afraid.  Give it a go!If the controls still bother you there are plenty of game modes, (including a free roam mode) starring different characters who are mostly easier to control than a bread slice.Gameplay:The variety is what makes this game stand out against most joke simulators.There is plenty to do, and the game isn't reliant on humour to succeed.You can enjoy a Star Wars parody, you can hunt for cheese, you can race baguettes, and you can plate up the dirtiest piece of bread you have ever seen with a smile on your face after skateboarding through dust, ants and falling in the dish water.This is a unique fun game that deserves a chance.  Give it a go.

								I'm not one who's opinion of games is extremely critical, however, I must say this: the controls are out of whack!No matter what you set the controls to, this is an extremely frustrating game. I am also frustrated that whoever lives in this house doesn't put the Bread near the toaster! How inconsiderate! Doesn't the person even think about how long of a journey Bread has to travel to fulfill his dreams of becoming toast? In conclusion, I must say that I love the idea, and it has potential, but until the controls are decent, I think I'll stick to mostly first-person shooter games. In my opinion, no, I wouldn't play it much. But if YOU have always dreamed of a game in which you play as a piece of bread becoming animate who has to suffer through loss of inedibility, GO RIGHT AHEAD! THUMBS UP! 10/10 BREAD SLICES!!!

content:
Posted: August 6, 2015
												This game is really great! and I know it looks like an intimidating buy, so I decided to put this together to help you decide!AHEM!!Darkness...Silence...And then,the flash of a knife in the dark I watch in horrible gut-wrenching anticipation I tenseand then...Pain!PAIN AS I HAVE NEVER FELT BEFORE!I wished with every precious milliecond of my short and inconsequential existance that the unbearable agony would cease!when suddenly...light....FREEDOMI pause... confused and exited. What is this wonderous feeling? for the first time, I wiggle my left corner... then my right... how? How is this possible? I squint around with my new found sight. At first the images make no coherent sense to me, colors and shapes swim before my eyes in a dance of choatic inanity. It seems to me that I am watching honey bear take supper with a family of badgers and a pair of rather snobish french ducklings. I see a butterfly flutter past, and my eyes follow it only to see it stop to perch on a Loaf of Bread.......could it be?surely my eyes must still be decieving me! but alas, as I peruse my surroundings for a second time I see nothing but a filthy kitchen with half empty bottles laying at random across the room. The counter top appeared to be overrun by a hoard of disgusting ants, and the table upon which I was laying seemed to have a Loaf of Bread sitting right in the middle, OF WHICH I WAS NOT A PART OF!I gasped in horrorIT WASN'T TRUE!it couldn't be!I? Seperated from my Loaf?I retreated within my self TRYING to regain the calm sense of quiet colaboration from which I was so violently torn!sure enough, I could no longer regain contact with my brethren.My soul despaired.but I am not one to sit and loaf about in a bad situation. I gripped the surface of the table with all of my might and flung myself headlong toward the edge. I peered over, shuddering to my self at the sight of the pathogen sullied floor a few feet below. I gazed across the gap at my destination, Took a moment to steele myself for the gravity defying leap, dug my corners into the table and pushed against it with such a force that it sent me careening into the air! There was a fleeting moment of despair as I realized that I would miss my intentended target, but I quickly regained my concentration to find a solution to my predicament. As I soared past the chair between the table and countertop, I managed to just grab the top with my left corner. For a moment I thought I was safe, but as I clung to the chair, it began to tip. Slowly at first, but then faster, and FASTER! I feared it would fall to the floor and crush me beneath its weight, but in mid fall the top of the chair hit the edge of the counter top... and stayed there! This was brilliant! I hoisted myself up from my precarius perch and up to the counter top just as the last of my grip strength ran out. I lay there gasping for breath as I let my tired corners rest. But it was no more than a minute or two's respite before I was compelled to flee from the newest danger of my harrowing journey. The ants. They ran on to me climbing up my white and fluffy sides as I tried hopelessly to shake them off. I could feel my precious edibility dropping as the ants crawled up and down my quivering body. I threw myself recklessly across the counter and began to climb the huge white expanse that was the refridgerator. As I climbed I began to feel better, as the ants were shaken off and hurled to their doom at the floor below. With a sudden realization I thought to myself that maybe... just maybe, this transformation from Loaf to Slice was a good thing! I was unlike any of my kind, I could move, I could breathe, I could SEE! I COULD HEAR! As I flipped myself over the top of the fridge I spied my destiation in the distance. A small, shiny metal toaster. Though the journey was far from over I knew it would be worth it, and I had many a reason to be encouraged. I was by all means, incredible! The soul triumph of NATURE! A GOD AMONG MY PEOPLE!!! I gaze at the lands over which I WILL NO DOUBT RULE!!!! and I find comfort in the fact that ....one day! I shall rule ALL GRAINS!!! every BAGEL and BAGUETTE!!! because from this moment on I AM KING!I... AM... BREAD!!!!...and that's only the first level!10/10 would rule again!

								9.5/10Only reason I give this a 9.5 is beacuse of the keyboard & mouse controlls, their a bit funky. With a controller, the game is pretty manageable. It's also a very fun and entertaining game, without a doubt. It's like Goat Simulator, but with bread. BREAD.If you like little quirky, fun, somewhat challenging, and bizzare games, this definately is well worth it. Now, I got it on sale for $8.49, and I believe $10 may be a bit much. For a game that's early access and is still somewhat buggy at times, I believe it's worth around $7.50. None the less, I reccomend this game if you like something you can♥♥♥♥♥♥around in.Once again, this game is almost made as a joke. Not implying that it's bad, but it's one of those jokes that in the past people would make fun of. "HAH! Who'd want to play a game where you're a slice of bread?" Apparently alot of people.KEEP IN MIND that the goal in this game is to become toast. By any means necessary. Be it Toaster or Radiator, your goal is to become toast.---Now i'll note why I believe the keyboard / mouse controlls are wonky.To grip onto things, you have 1,2,3, and 4. To grab things, you have Q,W,E, and R. To look around, you use Right Click, and to move around, you use Left Click. I believe this control scheme could have been improved in some fassion. Such as look around being locked onto the cursor.So ways I think they could improve the mouse & keyboard controlls;1. Make the camera snap to the cursor, so you look around by moving the mouse.2. Use a control layout that's a little bit more natural, for instance;---When I place my left hand on my keyboard, my fingers naturally will rest on (From left to right); Left Shift, A, W, D and the Space Bar. ---A Good Idea would be to change it from 1234 to LShift, A, D, and Space Bar, using W for push away from camera and S for being pull towards the camera (Or the direction that the camera is facing).---Another way to change the control scheme, is to do what's listed above, but change the camera look from mouse to arrow keys. This would make gameplay better on laptops, and users who prefer playing with a keyboard.The game is in early access, so again, things will change over time. Hopefully the controlls for keyboard/mouse will become more naturall over time.Aside from that, I do reccomend this fun quirky little game.

content:
Posted: March 28, 2016
												Do I recommend this game? Yes and no is the simple answer. The more elaborated answer is a bit more... complicated.Yes, I recommend it because:+ The ultimate challenge for your patience+ wonderful, playful music+ nice graphics+ excellent ideaBut I don't recommend it because:- It's way too hard and unforgiving for its own good (imho).- Short soundtrack - all though lovely, I only played like 70 minutes, and I already got tired of the soundtrackI want to comment a little bit more elaborated on the "too hard for its own good"-point here. I know this game is supposed to be hard, and I know it is the ultimate challenge. But in my opinion there are too many factors that makes you fail in order for this to be fun to play. Prior to ordering this game, I was just thinking that people were too bad gamers and soar loosers for down-voting this game due to its controls and being too hard. But now I understand them.It is hard enough to master navigating the bread; but once you learn that it's quite simple. HOWEVER, what I cannot grasp is why the most difficult aspect of this game is to get into the God forsaken toaster??? You've just been through hell to get to the toaster, and then you simply cannot get into the bloody thing. On the first story mission I mastered my skills to get to the toaster in like 3 - 4 minutes, which is quite good considering I just bought the game. But then you are rewarded by having to spend another 5 minutes to get the bread to actually go into the toaster. And that blew a fuse for me.The second thing that makes this game too difficult is how unforgiving it is; not only do you loose edibility (health), but also have a grip-counter which is way too short/small considering how you are sometimes supposed to hang above the floor infront of a grill in order to become toasted. It is also not rewarding enough. The grading scale in the end is way too demanding, which more often than not sends out a vibe that "Hey, You suck ballz!". I mean, I don't expect an A-grading for completing a mission in 10 minutes, but a D when I lost no health at all? That is just mean.So how to "fix" this game in my opinion? Make it a bit more forgiving; don't make it so difficult to get into the toaster after all the hell getting to the toaster, indicate WHAT is the toaster (it is difficult enough to get to it, you should not have to search for WHAT is the toaster), and make the toast more responsive to your controlls.All in all: If you like to torture yourself, and/or have an incredible amount of patience, this game is for you. The concept is brilliant. But considering the immense difficulty of the game I would not recommend this for the weak-minded (I guess I am a weak-minded gamer in this sense). My final verdict is a 7/10 for being a brilliant concept with good graphics and being a game that really stays true to its intended gameplay. But NO, I don't recommend this, unless you have some serious nerves of steel and is serious about sitting hours just to get through one or two levels of the game.

In Surgeon Simulator, for example, the failure is largely why the game is so much fun. But this is just bread. The humor doesn't last five minutes. I wouldn't recommend this game to anyone.

number of helpful: 20 of 35 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 30, 2015
												Of the numerous silly physics simulators, this one is the most artificially difficult and has the worst actual physics implementation: most movable objects will cause you to spaz out and possibly get launched across the level when you grab them, and your slice of bread has *way* too much mass -- I was able to hold a floor lamp by the lightbulb and Jerry Lewis it around the room with just my wiggling movements. That's one thing if I'm holding like an empty box, but a metal lamp? Few things behave like you expect them to, making each level less of a physics sandbox/puzzle and more of a trial and error hellscape. The final straw is the controls: mouse+kb is almost unusable, but you can rebind the keys, while a gamepad works pretty well, but is not rebindable -- so have fun with the god-awful default binds: you have to keep your fingers on the triggers *and* bumpers the whole time. This basically limits your gameplay time to 10-20 minutes, as any more than that will turn your hands into arthritic claws permanently. There are things to like about this game, but I wouldn't recommend spending more than $5 on it, and only then if you have a soft spot for goofy physics games. If they ever patch the physics to be less broken, it could be great, but as it stands, the physics are just too unpredictable.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2015
												I Am Bread will look like a niche knock off broken simulator like Goat Sim at first glance, but look at the developer. The people who made this game also made Surgeon Simulator. It too is a wacky but functional simulator with unique mechanics. You are a slice of bread meant to become toast by using the map to heat up your slice. That is a goal, something real games have. Goat Sim's only progression is racking up points. In I Am Bread, each level begins with a psychiatrist's diagnosis card. That's a story. It seems that the owner of the house believes that somebody is breaking into his home, destroying his things, and leaving one single slice of toast. As you play the game, you will see what happens to the guy.I Am Bread is a good game with minimal bugs and a lot of features and puns since it got out of early access. It is best played with a gamepad though.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								Good, silly experiences are hard to come by. Most end up just being one trick ponies and gimmick-a-thons. And the few decent ones end up being more like physics toys than actual games (Looking at you Turbo Dismount).I am Bread turns out to be an actual GAME rather than a toy. It's challenging, strategic and most importantly fun to play. The game is rather short. Right now there are 4 levels, each of which you could beat in 5 minutes (you won't, but you could). It took me 3 hours to complete. Might take a little longer if you choose to explore more.Most levels have alternate routes and if that's not enough you could just scoot along the ceiling.I've seen people complain about the controls, and I admit, the keyboard controls are pretty horrofic, so I suggest you use a controller. Learning and mastering the controls is the main challenge. You start out clumsily flopping around, smashing everything your way. And by the end you'll be making flips from wall to wall like a preschooler on acid.Cons mostly consist of some unwarranted failures due to wonky physics knocking over a toaster you desperately need. The learning curve is pretty harsh too. And the lack of real tutorial can be an issue if you get frustrated easily.Overall. The game if real fun. It didn't feel samey and I can't wait for more to come.A nod to the developers for showing us that a dumb game doesn't have to be braindead.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
												BUY/SALE/PASS:  Sale - Wait for a sale priceAbout ten years ago, there came along a budget title out of Japan named Katamari Damacy.  In the tiny feet of a diminutive prince, players were tasked with picking up whatever random crap was strewn around a room/house/neighborhood/city/planet as fast as you can.  It was strange, yet strangely compelling; an oddity of video games that came out of nowhere and has since been milked dry as a concept; even the original creator has distanced himself from the series.  Weird games slowly drift by the wayside as video games break way into the mainstream, and things become normal.Then, in 2015, players were tasked with playing as a slice of bread.Bossa Studios, the creators of Surgeon Simulator 2013, bring us yet another bizarro creation.  As a single slice of bread, your mission in I am Bread is to get toasted by any means necessary.  Gripping the surfaces and objects around you with the corners of your bread slice (somehow…), you must traverse the various rooms of a house to find that sweet embrace of heat that will get you nice and crispy.  But don’t land anywhere gross or linty!  Otherwise you’ll end up inedible, and what will even be the point of being toasted?  The horror of such a thought!I am Bread is utter nonsense baked into a bizarre, fluffy bun.  Yet the gameplay is so fun and goofy, oftentimes creating some of the best accidentally funniest moments of any game released this year.  Purposefully frustrating controls leave the player pulling out their hair one moment and laughing the next.  There’s no escaping it.  You are bread.  And you will be toast, one way or another.  Delightful music, fun gameplay, funky concept, all worthy of a sale price purchase.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												I am Bread may strike people as a novelty game, but it has some real meat behind its fluffy appearance. The amazingly weird premise is bolstered by an intriguing control scheme and physics-based gameplay.  Though it has some crusty edges around its soft center, it has more than enough freshness to warrant a recommendation at its whole sale value. As an autonomous piece of bread, your main objective is to move from the rest of the stilted loaves to a place in the same room where you can become toasted. Environmental hazards like used band-aids and dirt reduce your edibility, forcing you to find different pathways as you jitter and flip your way around the house with the shoulder buttons and the left analog stick. The variety is surprising, as you'll find multiple ways to flip, toss, and jiggle your bread with the shoulder buttons. It might be weirdly unintuitive at first, but with practice, the controls become quite natural. It ultimately becomes a key part of the game from easily becoming a stale novelty. Suffice it to say though, a controller is a must. The keyboard and mouse combo would only wreck your hands. The crusty parts eluded to earlier involve a camera that can sometimes work against you. The angle can change quickly, altering the way the controls and forcing you to compensate for it. It happens infrequently, but leaves an irritating impression when it does happen. The environment could also use some life to it, as aside from the multiple ways to become toasted, there isn't much else to do in it. Some challenging trigger events like turning on the TV (which I found disappointingly unresponsive in the second level), or even a combo of related actions could have added much more value. Nonetheless, I am Bread provides fresh, delicious scent to an indie landscape overstuffed with me-too first-person shooter and rogue-lite games. Highly recommended for those looking for a new, action-oriented game and recommended still for everyone else.

content:
Posted: August 2, 2016
												If you've ever wondered what would happen if you mashed QWOP and OctoDad together I Am Bread is it. You play a piece of bread on a quest to get toasted in each level, using various items such as irons or radiators or frying pans. Touching the floor or any other dirty surface will reduce your edibility percentage and once that hits 0% you lose.Unfortunately, the game’s engine and programming also mean you will have to battle with the camera randomly adjusting itself on certain angles and the bread ragdolling around spastically from time to time. You can alleviate this to some degree by predicting which corner will contact next during a flip and hold that corner’s respective button down but even that can be a guessing game. Keeping in mind, your grip meter is counting down the entire time you are holding any buttons down so you’re on a time limit until you reach stable ground. After a few rounds of flailing and failure the game will throw you a bone by giving you an invincibility power up although using it basically removes any challenge from the game.I Am Bread is one of those games where you either love the concept or hate it, and I couldn’t find anything to love about it. Maybe it’s just me, but I would rather spend time fighting bad guys than my own controller.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2014
												A game where I am a piece of bread, made by the creators of Surgeon Simulator, with a decent premise and annoying controls... "I'm so in," sucker me said. I fork out the asking price, start up and am impressed by the settings options better than some games. Choose controller option, then realize I can't navigate menus (including restarting) with my controller still need mouse for that, not fun annoyed starts. Ok start playing, controller seems way better then keyboard and OMG, I'm controlling a piece of bread go me... but soon I realized the controls are about 10 times more horrible then surgeon simulator, the collision detection is horrible, collision detection can also be influenced by camera angles, and the camera angels are forced and hard to get a decent line of sight. Furthermore the lacking camera angles prevent you from being able to see the level and the game lacks a free roam mode with no edibility so you can explore. I have played early access games thinking this has potential, however I feel this game isn't even developed to the point where you can tell yet. Also the question "how do you control a piece of bread?", was not answered very well by the devs. Until I see some major improvements in playability I would not recommend this game! If in the future this game does improve, I will update my review.UPDATE: So since my original review the game has receiceved quite a bit of content and polish. Of the content I enjoyed the startch wars, the controls were actually playable but couldn't figure out what to do after destroying three weak points on the main ship. I gave up on the bagel race but felt like the rampage control where pretty good. I also found 0-gravity mode fun but sill nearly impossible to controll, there was cheese hunt and free roam but those are thing I only do with my girl friend so I didn't give them a shot. I tried tutorial mode and it took my a minute to realize they disabled the joystick in tutorial mode which really made me think why!? am I alway suposed to be controlling my bread with the d-pad? The other thing I realized was that the menus are still not fully navigatable with a controller so overall I just can't recommend this game to people, the video makes it look like fun but then you play it's just too difficult to enjoy the experience.

Early Access Review
								A wholly enjoyable experience. I cannot recall another protagonist I was capable of identifying with so well. The dialogue was dripping with passion, however in a manner still completely believable to us as spectators into our hero's perilous predicament. Scintillating graphical quality paired with impeccable level design will surely impress as innovative yet immersive controls are sure to whisk you away from your everyday life into the world of the game. If you do not purchase this game you are a cretin, a fool, and I whole-heartedly feel sorry for such a pitiful creature for having not experienced such an unbelievably exceptional masterpice of digital interactive cinema.

content:
Posted: April 16, 2015
Don't confuse I am Bread with an easy casual game where you can sit back and relax, you will be yelling at your computer and banging on the keyboard quite a lot. I love the difficult controls, it takes quite a while to learn them. It has a funny theme, and complex level design.  EDIT: Both glitches I mentioned are fixed now! Thanks, Bossa Studios, I guess you are really listening to your users!My only problems with this game has been that it doesn't work with my controller, a generic Logitech USB game controller. It also bugs out a lot when I try to move the camera, either making me look straight up, or directly down. Although these bugs are an aggravation, they are understandable, seeing that this game just reached it's full release about a week ago. Definitely a good game if you like crazy controls and excessive difficulty.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 20, 2016
												You play as a piece of bread with a singular goal: stop at nothing to become toast!  But wait, you must also be edible, so no crawling around on the floor as you complete your quest for a toaster.You can individually control each of the four corners of your slice of bread, and each corner can be used to grab something.  The bread flops around with ragdoll physics as you strategically alternate between corners in order to flip your way to a suitable toaster.  Controlling the bread is unbelievably difficult, and made worse by poor camera movement, but you do get the hang of it after a few hours of severe frustration.  Thankfully, repeatedly failing every level allows you to optionally become invincible and complete the level without worrying about your edibility.If the toaster is broken how do I become toast?Each level has multiple methods that will allow you to become toast. You can turn on the radiator, break the tv, use the iron, light the grill... the list goes on.  There are also several possible paths to reach each, so you can play each level several times.The game has quite a bit of humor in it.  Story mode allows you to watch as your owner slowly goes insane.  Starch Wars mode allows you to fly around in a spaceship made from a slice of bread in order to save a baguette.  Team Fortress 2 mode requires you to become a Sandvich.  Other modes have you race around as a bagel, break things as a baguette, find cheese as a cracker, etc.  My personal favorite is Zero Gravity where you can soar through the house.I think the game is worth a shot, despite the incredibly difficult controls.  Just remember, Nobody wants to eat soggy bread.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								As you have probably inferred, this is one of the many goofy "simulator" games that steam has become famous for.  However, going into the game with this in mind, you may have a surprise coming your way.  I'm actually really enjoying this games "puzzles".  If super monkey ball was a childhood favorite of yours, expect good things(that is honestly what came to mind while playing this).  As for my reccommendations for the developers... PLEASE  make a level involving nothing else aside from teleporting yourself for 3 days.  The reference cannot go undone.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 9, 2015
												I Am Bread ♥♥♥♥in' ROCKS, lemme tell ya why.Pros:+Original concept+Wonky physics+Controller support+Many bread types to play as+Creative ways to toast yourself+Hard, but not impossible gameplay+Freaking bagel+Creative setupsCons:-Horrible keyboard controls-Sometimes the physics will break, and while this is mostly hilarious, it will kill you 99% of the time-Certain areas of walls and floor will kill you faster with no warning-Lots of trial and error (This can be a good thing, but here with the sometimes frustrating controls, it can get a little annoying)FINAL SCORE: 7/10With this game's wonderful concept and overall fun feel, you're bound to sink a few hours into it the first time you play. However, fragile physics and almost insta-kill areas of walls and floor can bog it down.

								I Am Bread is a heartbreaking, dramatizing, indepth story of 1 piece of breads amazing story of glory, fame, and toast. In this jaw-dropping plot twist Bread faces immense problems and obsticles that YOU the player muust help Bread get over. Experience the amazing story yourself and buy this award-winning game.

Its art... A dream becoming something you work hard towards while the story is a struggle through and through and over coming obstacles that are symbols for our everyday struggles and when you achieve the toast status it makes you ask yourself one final question... "What even is toast?"Maybe there is a small piece of toast in each of us...Last words about the game... It might infact not be a game. But the meaning of life and the struggle we all go through on a cosmical scale while trying to find our own toaster.Toast is love, Toast is life.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 2, 2015
												When I saw this game for the first time, I thought it's just a "meme" cash grab kind of game, which will provide you with about 5 minutes of amusement. But let me tell you, that's nowhere near the truth.✓ The game is actually quite hard.✓ Full story mode.✓ Several game modes. (there's like 5)✓ Free updates.✓ Low price tag.✓ Devs listen to feedback.Also, I've seen few people say "bad controls" in the recommendation. I disagree, you can change the control scheme as you please. The difficulty of moving around is clearly a design choice, just like in Surgeon Simulator.After Surgeon Simulator, this game convinces me that Bossa Studios are a great development studio and I am excited to see what they manage to create in the future.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
												This game is meant to make you realize what you truly are. You play as a piece of bread who goes on a massive adventure to become toasted like it always wanted, and sometimes picks up unwanted things like fishbones or bandaids that wear down your edibility. But the deeper meaning is clear. The bread is you, as you traverse through obsticles of life to become what you always wanted, but along the way you collect memories that change who you are, and once you hit 0% you know your dreams are over. I cried a little after I realized what it meant, and I will never forget. I rate this masterpiece 10/10.

 DISCLAIMER: This is a first impressions review, and NOT a full review, if you want a full review, then please read better reviews then mine I am Bread is a game developed and published by Bossa Studios UKI liked I am Bread for its unique gameplay and ideas but it can get boring really quicklyYou have to have a good controller though (XBOX 360 controller recommended) to really be able to play the game, keyboard and mouse isn't really playableIt's a platformer at it's core and you have to toast yourself to beat each level avoiding dirty food, walls, and floorsThere are glitches and other bugs in the game. I'm sure they will iron out all the glitches and add more content in the near future so I would recommend this game only if you are not easily bored RECOMMENDED :)

content:
Posted: December 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								I bought this game expecting a semi relaxing puzzle game but instead I got an inner insight to my own madness as I delved deeper into the what bread truly is. Bread is The Devil in edible form. Its inability to get toasted and my own determination to get the perfectly toasted morsel formed an ungodly combination  worthy of the book of revelations. I Would die and repeat as what little momentum I could generate was trampled under the ever darkening floor. As my many attempts of toasted glory ended up in trash I couldn't think clearly and the useall part of my brain that was used for sleeping eating and various other important tasks is filled with bread and anger towards the the most clingy hated force in the universe, Gravity. Would I recommend this game if you are sane and would like to stay sane? no. If you want to be insane and have yet to be then yes, but if you already have lost your marbles then you've already played the game and reading the review is waist of your time. You should be running naked down the streets.
