content:
Posted: December 8, 2016
												well you're bread..........and your goal is to become toast though i'm sure you already know that if you read the description.i am bread is a unique game about using your sticky corners to grip to the enviroinment and fling yourself to victory! though like any good game this is easier said than done, being bread you have to make sure that your eddibility doesn't go below 1% or you lose, so you need to avoid the floor, dirt, and other things you wouldn't want on you're toast. to be more specific on the controls on a key board you use the 1 2 3 and 4 keys to stick to objects the q w e r keys to hold objects and use the mouse to fling yourself whatever way depending on what keys your pressing (you can change these in the settings) but don't ignore the warning for most people it works WAAAAY better with a controller (i am not most people) if you use a controller these are the control equivelents: RB LB RT LB =  1 2 3 4 a b y x buttons = q w e rLS = mouseyou also have grades in this game A++ = best time, 90% eddibility, and never running out of grip F= failed the leveloh and that's another thing i should mention when you press any of your corners to make them sticky a grip meter starts running out if it runs out you automaticly let go of whatever you're holding ussally meaning you fall into some dirtthere's multiple modes in this game too there's cheese hunt where you play as a cracker and have to collect cheese no eddibility to worry about but you have integrity meaning if you smack yourself to hard or fall you lose integrity lose too much and you lose there's rampage where you're a beugettue and you have no gri[p meter no eddibility or integrityinstead you have a time limit to smash as much as you can there's zero G which puts the bread on rockets and you have to become toast like that. i could go on but i'm sure you want to be done reading this game has alot go buy it!BTW don't toast yourself in real life.

content:
Posted: December 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								Now that I've had a decent amount of time with the controls & have played through all 4 available levels I believe I can write my own take on the game. Note: I'm not great at this game, I have failed countless times. This is all based on my experience as someone playing this for fun & taking my time towards the goal.I am Bread, from the makers of another favorite of mine Surgeon Simulator, leaves you in control of a slice of bread as you try to toast yourself by any means possible. I love the concept itself; it's silly, fun and frustrating beyond belief. It's more of a hit or miss if you'll like it. I'd suggest watching the game play and understanding that the controls are difficult and the game isn't completely serious before you buy it & suddenly find yourself upset because it's not perfect. It's Early Access & the developers are still adding a lot to this so I'm pretty content with what we have so far, though there's still a long way to go. *This means go to the Discussions and make suggestions, not whine over not besting the controls in 20 minutes* With that said...Pros:- You are bread- You can roll in jam & butter to aid you in your goal- Be creative! There are other ways to heat bread other than a toaster, have fun with it.- A short narrative that follows our destructive path.- You can crawl in cereal or other things.- Make your heat source with destruction.- Smash things.- Take your time, have fun!- Playing/Watching this over live broadcast with a group of friends is very entertaining.- Procrastination simulator.Cons:- The controls are hard. I don't see any way of this being improved, to be honest. It takes time to get used to them but once you are it's more of a challenge of not touching the floor.- The floor is lava. - This guy's house is disgusting. There are some walls you can't touch without dying if you don't respond fast enough. The carpet is not always so forgiving depending where you land.- The grip meter is necessary but it goes from fun to frustrating when you spend all that time climbing but you miss a beat & drop onto the nasty carpet again.- The timer. I beat a level in 5 minutes without soiling my bread & I made a D at best. Unless you're hardcore going for that heat source I wouldn't expect a great rating.- The camra angles.- ^ I stepped on hair & couldn't see it at first.- He's worried about bread wrecking his house yet he has garbage/germs littered everywhere. Why did you even leave the loaf out.- I have a hard time removing the top concealing the butter.- Please make the counters less "edgy" in some aspects. I realize desks & the like have an edge sticking out on top but at times it's nearly impossible for me to get over that tiny lump.Possible Bugs:- I can't seem to lift myself up vertically with 3 & 4 anymore the way I do with 1 & 2.- After flinging myself along the wall I can only grip again with maybe 1 or 2 keys or my bread won't grip at all.- On the bathroom level I always drop down & end up grasping the toothpaste. This causes it to spasm in all directions and nearly send me flying.Possible suggestions could go on forever so I'll just leave it at this. Enjoy bread simulator & if you're thinking about whining instead of a "this is why I don't like/recommend this game," turn off your computer & walk away. 10/10

content:
Posted: December 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								Now that I've had a decent amount of time with the controls & have played through all 4 available levels I believe I can write my own take on the game. Note: I'm not great at this game, I have failed countless times. This is all based on my experience as someone playing this for fun & taking my time towards the goal.I am Bread, from the makers of another favorite of mine Surgeon Simulator, leaves you in control of a slice of bread as you try to toast yourself by any means possible. I love the concept itself; it's silly, fun and frustrating beyond belief. It's more of a hit or miss if you'll like it. I'd suggest watching the game play and understanding that the controls are difficult and the game isn't completely serious before you buy it & suddenly find yourself upset because it's not perfect. It's Early Access & the developers are still adding a lot to this so I'm pretty content with what we have so far, though there's still a long way to go. *This means go to the Discussions and make suggestions, not whine over not besting the controls in 20 minutes* With that said...Pros:- You are bread- You can roll in jam & butter to aid you in your goal- Be creative! There are other ways to heat bread other than a toaster, have fun with it.- A short narrative that follows our destructive path.- You can crawl in cereal or other things.- Make your heat source with destruction.- Smash things.- Take your time, have fun!- Playing/Watching this over live broadcast with a group of friends is very entertaining.- Procrastination simulator.Cons:- The controls are hard. I don't see any way of this being improved, to be honest. It takes time to get used to them but once you are it's more of a challenge of not touching the floor.- The floor is lava. - This guy's house is disgusting. There are some walls you can't touch without dying if you don't respond fast enough. The carpet is not always so forgiving depending where you land.- The grip meter is necessary but it goes from fun to frustrating when you spend all that time climbing but you miss a beat & drop onto the nasty carpet again.- The timer. I beat a level in 5 minutes without soiling my bread & I made a D at best. Unless you're hardcore going for that heat source I wouldn't expect a great rating.- The camra angles.- ^ I stepped on hair & couldn't see it at first.- He's worried about bread wrecking his house yet he has garbage/germs littered everywhere. Why did you even leave the loaf out.- I have a hard time removing the top concealing the butter.- Please make the counters less "edgy" in some aspects. I realize desks & the like have an edge sticking out on top but at times it's nearly impossible for me to get over that tiny lump.Possible Bugs:- I can't seem to lift myself up vertically with 3 & 4 anymore the way I do with 1 & 2.- After flinging myself along the wall I can only grip again with maybe 1 or 2 keys or my bread won't grip at all.- On the bathroom level I always drop down & end up grasping the toothpaste. This causes it to spasm in all directions and nearly send me flying.Possible suggestions could go on forever so I'll just leave it at this. Enjoy bread simulator & if you're thinking about whining instead of a "this is why I don't like/recommend this game," turn off your computer & walk away. 10/10

content:
Posted: December 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								The game has been fully released now s I thought it best to update my review.Still virtually unplayable with the controls it has. Moving around is beyond silly. What makes it worse is the lag in controls as well.  I'm running a i7 and this game still has delays within the control system.Graphics are mediocre at best. (And this is final version?)There IS a goal of trying to toast yourself. Exciting.Anyway, if you hit the floor you die very quickly. Move on other objects and they smash. Not sure if I am meant to smash all the objects or what but that seems the high point of gameplay.Its general control has improved slightly since alpha, BUT there is still virtually no control of the main player.  The bread apparently has suction cups on the corners but they only last a little while. You end up just flopping around and spinning in circles. Movement is based more on luck that skill.Game itself seems aimed at either little children who may get a thrill out of flopping around like soggy bread, or those that may be easily amused (or those with child like mentallity.) There is no real purpose to the levels or real storyline. I gather its meant to be a bit of a joke type game but really the gameplay is the joke. The developers seem to have had enough of the game, and released it as "Final" rather than fix up the bugs, poor graphics, poor gameplay and contolability issues.They did add some silly levels that appear to have been done in a rush just for basic content fill, but none of those add anything to the game overall.Contrary to all the silly coments and juvenile jokes, the only joke is developers charging for this.For anyone looking for a game that is challenging, fun to play, and value for money - LOOK ELSEWHERE! This game is not worth it, and although while it was in alpha I had slim hopes they would improve it, now that it supposedly finished, it is not worth the time of day.AVOID!If you want to join the kiddy clubs and make silly jokes then spend your "bread" on this, and enjoy a half baked crusty game. Just another way to blow your dough!  Isn't that fun - </sarcasm>

content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								Where do I even start with this game? The emotions, the journey, all of it. Amazing. I cried at the end of the game. Such a touching ending. Truly, this gives one a true perspective of what it's like to be toast, and while doing so pokes at the qualities that make us who we are. This game was an emotional rollercoaster, going from fun and hilarious to serious and philosophical. This made me question reality itself, for I think I may have been a piece of toast in a past life. Like the glory of the sun, this game is a shining hope for humanity and gaming. Call of Duty and all those other "next gen" console games are nothing in comparison to this glorious and heartfelt game. All in all I give this game an 11/10, for this game has changed my life for the better.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 16, 2016
												QWOP with toast.If you aren't familiar with QWOP, it is a game where you have to control someone's individual joints to make them run/walk. It is incredibly awkward as a control scheme and is basically a joke game.I Am Bread is basically that, except instead of controlling a person, you control a piece of toast. You can stick one or more of the corners of the bread to a surface in order to move, flipping over and over again to get around the level. You can stick to anything, and ultimately, the game is a bit of a physics puzzle.The problem is that the incredibly awkward controls are endlessly frustrating. Getting into the toaster in the first level is an arduous, unpleasant task which takes an enormous amount of work. The toast flops around freely and almost uncontrollably, and while it is not that hard to simply move around large, flat surfaces, any sort of specific positioning is an awful, awful chore.And that's just the first level.This game is endlessly frustrating and unless you actually, genuinely enjoyed QWOP, this game will drive you batty.

content:
Posted: April 15, 2015
												The controls are frustrating to the point of not being any fun at all.  Movement is partially based on camera placement which can make things really awkward.  And that's not the worst of it.  The extra game modes bring in some interesting variety, but not enough.  There's no fun to be had here, there's not even any novelty that wears off quickly.  The controls are so hard to grasp that I didn't find myself having any fun and didn't have time to learn the controls before the novelty wore off.  Maybe if there was some sort of multiplayer this game might be worth the purchase, but I don't see it being worth anywhere near $10 at the moment.  Maybe $2.50.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								I just beat the last room in Early Access and I have to say that this is a great game. It’s quite simple; you are a piece of bread on a quest to become toasted. The controls definitely take some getting used to, as they are much different than many other games. After some time though, it becomes easier. But when you are falling to the floor because your grip ran out, it becomes a little hectic and difficult to get the right buttons. The music is catchy and tends to get stuck in your head. Though, in a good way. I would definitely recommend this.

content:
Posted: November 19, 2016
												My Grandfather smoked his whole life. I was about 10 years old when my mother said to him. "if you ever want to see your grandchildren graduate. you have to stop immediately." Tears welled up in his eyes when he realized what exacly was at stake. He gave it up immediately. Three years later he died of lung cancer. It was really sad and destroyed me. My mother said to me - "Don't ever smoke. Please don't put your family through what your Grandfather put us through". I agreed. At 27, i have never touched a cigarette. I must say. I feel a very slight sense of regret for never having done it, because this game gave me cancer anyway.

content:
Posted: June 6, 2016
												This game has some very hard controls but with a controller it is way better. The game is very fun and I do like Bossa Studios games because they do not give you the easiest controls they want to challenge you in a way you will rage. But boy does it feel good beating one of the levels, I have played up to level 3 in the story so far but there are other things to do like Rampage where you destroy everything. There is Ram-Page where you are the goat simulator goat destroying everything. There is Zero Gravity, that is where you just float around and try to get toasted. There is Starch Wars, where you are the piece of Bread like a tie-fighter, I haven't played starch wars too much so I do not no they objective. There is also bagel race where you are a bagel rolling around the house trying to get all the checkpoints and get to the finish line in the shortest amount of time. This game is extremley fun I would give it a 9/10. I ussualy give 10/10, but at first it is so hard that I had to take away 1 so. content:

Early Access Review
								To play this game is to understand the compelled nature of a salmon each spawn. You'll face the same adversity as the noble Sockeye, adversity such as making seemingly impossible jumps, climbing amazing obstacles and defying physics as we understand them. The futility of life is put on beautiful display as each run ends with the death of our hero so that the species might propagate... into a bread slot.I feel like I learned about the monumental daily struggles of bread, and that I now have a much greater understanding of myself, of my place in this world. At around 10.00USD, you too can experience this life-defining title.10/10

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												I spent 1 hour into this and this is my story,-Becomes bread-Shuffles my way over to the table-Dies-Dies over and over again-Tries for the last time-Falls over on the floor by accident-Screams-Gets up with 70% edibility thinking I can still do this-My spirit gets me to the fabulous toaster-I feel amazing as I try my very best to get inside the toaster-Bread does 10 backflips in the air randomly and lands in cat litter-Dies-Rage Quit But, In all honesty, I actually think the game is slighty decent (but quite annoying and quite challenging) and I do think that the sound track its awesome, but the controls are really annoying and I think that if I were to get the game on a console or at least something with a controller, I would enjoy it a bit more (even though that is not the game fault, still (please read the below section  labelled UPDATE to answer this)). I am going to say though that this game isn't for everyone. I wouldn't reccommend this game for people who just rush into an area on COD with no mental stratergy or skill. You need to ability to stay calm in stressful situations and think about what you are going to do. However, on the Keyboard and Mouse, I don't think this game is any good. I dont think with a controller it is that good to buy. Even with all that said, I don't think the game is worth £10. I did get it on sale (but obviously requested a refund) for £2.49 but if it weren't on sale, I would say a good price is £4.99 or lower (in my opinion, I would rather get other games than this). 4/10 total but If I did have a controller (which isn't the games fault that I don't have a controller but stil), maybe 4.5/10UPDATE:A comment recently came in from the developer of the game (Colm_Ahern) telling me about controller support.Yeah I did realise there is controller support but a controller isn't the only problem with the game. The game is slighty decent in terms of graphics and humor but the controls of the game (the way you have to grip the corners in the way the bread moves) and don't even get me started on the toaster. I got to the toaster over 10 times and not once could I mangage to get the bread inside the toaster (not just me who struggled with that). Also, the camera angles are really annoying and the bread can sometimes do 10 backflips in the air when you get the toaster and lands somewhere in the level nowhere near the toaster for no apparent reason and then land somewhere in the level no where near the toaster. Futhermore, the bread can move a whole fullsize wooden chair but not a salt shaker? Really? I think to make this game good please, change the controls (the way the bread grips, not a controller - although a controller may help, the controls are still not good), fix the camera angles and I think that it the bread touches the top of the toaster, the bread should go inside the toaster, not the player having to do that. And I saw many friends and youtubers struggle with that aswell (alot of youtubers never even got inside the toaster).

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 6, 2015
												I went into this game expecting what everyone else was when they first saw this game. A physics based game like surgeon simulator, but a platformer. Surely this was headed towards amazing comedic effect and fun gameplay, right? well you're an idiot if you still think that after more than an hour of playing this processed horse urine. Not only does it control like a drunk clown trying to do a balancing act while sucking on a cats nipples, but it feels like walking through a pool of molasses and rusty nails. You could ram your head on the sidewalk outside of your house for an hour and get the same effect that this game would give you. I'm sick of people saying this game is funny, or fun in general. It looks like something a college freshman cooked up on unity with 20 minutes of work and a $3 budget. It makes me ashamed that I decided to play this trash, and i'm even more ashamed that i played all the game modes trying to find something good. Except bagel, Bagel knows whats up. but you cant even enjoy him because he only has like 6 levels; then it's back to the same awkward controls that give me a brain tumor. Maybe if you sat down and really tried to master this games controls while also ignoring the graphics that look like something a dog would throw up, but doing so would be cruel and unusual torture. This game makes me feel like hanging myself. the end

content:
Posted: July 27, 2015
												As much as I love breaking glass and caressing my naked body with jam. When it comes to games I like to be able to use the camera controls to see the space infront of me, not to stare at the small patch of wall behind me whilst trying to blindly move.This game holds a mass of novelty factor that makes it playable, but once you get over that all thats left is a challenging game with horrid controls, extremely rigid camera settings and levels that punish you for small errors (which happen easily due to the controls and camera).7/10 for the first hour or so.Take away an additional 1/10 for every 5 minutes after you've became toast on a flaming tv that you crushed with a conveniently placed bowling bowl on the shelf above it.This game is worth if on a good sale but otherwise save your money for pizza :)))

								If you've heard anything about this game, then you already know that it's difficult. However, if you choose to play this game, then I can NOT stress enough the importance of keeping calm, throughout this game. content:
Posted: June 30, 2015
												I Am Bread I guess would best be defined as a puzzle/adventure game, for it certainly has aspects of both genres. You may or may not like this game. If you're like me, you brought the game because of the interesting title name and backstory.That said backstory is that you literally play as bread. You are some guy's bread, and you need to move around his house haphazardly in order to 'toast' yourself. I thought this title would be worth a look, so I went ahead and brought it, and soon found out that this was a hard game.I'm not opposed to challenge. Some of the best games of all times were also the hardest. Challenge however shouldn't come in the form of bad camera angles and shoddy controls.The idea behind I am bread is interesting, but once the novelty wears off, you'll probably find the game to be lackluster. Spending ages climbing up a fridge only to have you work undone by the punishing game mechanics isn't fun. It's tedious and boring. And once you get to the top of the fridge, you have to  proceed down a linear path in order to climb the next obstacle.Ultimately, my point is this. You are apiece of bread which climbs things. There are literally only three or four game play elements that provide challenge. These game play elements are nothing new or exciting, and certainly not worth the price of this game.If you can get it on sale, it might be worth a try. As it stands however, I Am Bread leaves a lot to be desired with me. This could have been an interesting game, but it is just so... boring, repetitive and tedious.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								***A NOTE to those having issues on PC: I played on the lowest and the highest graphics settings with keyboard and mouse and although the game ran smoothly on my beefy computer in both cases, the bread handled absolutely terribly in low settings. In high settings the kayboard/mouse performed just as well if not better than when I played with a controller! So if you're having troubles experiment with different graphics settings. This issue may or may not get better as the game is worked on as it is currently in Early Access as I'm writing this review.***If the above or below is helpful to you please thumb up so it can be helpful to others as well :-)Here's the "what you need to know": Control the 4 corners of a piece of bread to navigate across levels and find a way to make yourself into toast. It's much harder than it sounds as the bread is quite difficult to control. You can move and break most anything in a level so sometimes it's fun getting sidetracked and just break stuff. As you move your way up along objects and walls your "Grip" meter diminishes and when it's empty you fall prey to gravity, but it recharges after a second of not climbing. Also, avoid gross things in a level, namely the floor, ants, etc, as coming into contact will decrease your edibility, which is the games equicalent of a health bar. THAT'S IT! That's everything you need to know to jump in and have fun with I Am Bread.I've posted a brief and comical video of my playtime with the game on the I Am Bread community page, which can be seen here if you want to see my experience with the game firsthand: 


YouTube™ Video: I Am Bread - Bread Man Walking - Full HD 

			Views: 346		

			Join me on Bread's quest for FREEEEEDOM!!! Bread always dreamed of becoming Toast, so he set out to do so. However, Bread isn't very good at walking, or climbing, or moving, or anything at all for...

content:
Posted: September 29, 2016
												Here's my take on this game: it's fun. It's a great concept, the game modes are different enough to keep you busy, and even the story is intriguing (props for the way its told too). And it's pretty challenging, which are all things I like. HOWEVER, I gave this game a thumbs up after much consideration, even though I wanted to give it a thumbs down first. READ BELOW. I CAN'T RECOMMEND THIS GAME NOR CAN I NOT RECOMMEND IT.Why? Because it doesn't work properly. Maybe it's my Windows version, maybe it's my controller, I don't know. Maybe it will work for you, but I had to do some work just to get it to run, and after that, I've had controller issues galore. This is a game that relies on precision timing and holding down buttons at the same time: imagine how WONDERFUL it is to have buttons randomly let go, making you fall down for no reason after wasting 30+ minutes getting from the starting point to around 80% of the level. Not to mention I have to literally mash any button in the menu to select items. I tried talking to the devs, they did give some suggestions, I tried them but they didn't work (with two different controllers, mind you) so in the end, it's too bad Steam doesn't offer a "neutral" recommendation option; working properly, it's a good game (keyboard-mouse work fine for me), but "buyer beware" as David Vincent would say.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								So, I've barely gotten more than half-an-hour on the game, but so far so good, I think.Your goal, as bread, is to become toast.  There are various scenarios, but since I haven't become toast yet, or even close, I can only speak to the first one.  You start off on the kitchen table and have to make your way to, presumably, a toaster, without touching the floor for too long.  The longer you are on the floor, the less edible you become until you finally lose the level.The mechanics are tough to get used to, even more menacing than Octodad.  Each side of the toast is assigned a key and you have to decide which corner is your pivot point and move the mouse.  You have a "grip meter" for moving up surfaces, like climbing the refrigerator or the cabinets, so this adds an extra, "time sensitive" element to it.Overall, I really have liked it so far.  Seems like it will provide a lot of very fun and challenging play.  If you want to see the gameplay, I did make a video:


YouTube™ Video: I Am Bread - Part 1 

			Views: 367		

			I am a slice of bread who dreams of some day becoming toast.

Posted: March 27, 2016
												Have you ever wanted to be a slice of bread struggling for survival as you hold on to just about anything you can imagine just to keep off the floor so your owner can devour you? Then this is the game for you! The floor, isn`t the only problem you`ll have to solve either, there are fish bones, ants, band aids, and other huge problems for a slice of bread that you`ll have to solve!Reality though, this game is pretty hard as you first start but the controls aren`t too confusing to get a grip on. If you don`t have much patience then I really wouldn`t buy this game. I haven`t encountered any glitches but there is a grip meter and it can make the game difficult. There is also the "edible" meter which is pretty self explanitory. If you hit the floor, ants, dirt, etc. your meter will go down and then you cannot be eaten. If you fail enough times the game will pity you and just make you invincible if you choose to be. This game is difficult yet fun.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2016
												Here's my take on this game: it's fun. It's a great concept, the game modes are different enough to keep you busy, and even the story is intriguing (props for the way its told too). And it's pretty challenging, which are all things I like. HOWEVER, I gave this game a thumbs up after much consideration, even though I wanted to give it a thumbs down first. READ BELOW. I CAN'T RECOMMEND THIS GAME NOR CAN I NOT RECOMMEND IT.Why? Because it doesn't work properly. Maybe it's my Windows version, maybe it's my controller, I don't know. Maybe it will work for you, but I had to do some work just to get it to run, and after that, I've had controller issues galore. This is a game that relies on precision timing and holding down buttons at the same time: imagine how WONDERFUL it is to have buttons randomly let go, making you fall down for no reason after wasting 30+ minutes getting from the starting point to around 80% of the level. Not to mention I have to literally mash any button in the menu to select items. I tried talking to the devs, they did give some suggestions, I tried them but they didn't work (with two different controllers, mind you) so in the end, it's too bad Steam doesn't offer a "neutral" recommendation option; working properly, it's a good game (keyboard-mouse work fine for me), but "buyer beware" as David Vincent would say.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								So, I've barely gotten more than half-an-hour on the game, but so far so good, I think.Your goal, as bread, is to become toast.  There are various scenarios, but since I haven't become toast yet, or even close, I can only speak to the first one.  You start off on the kitchen table and have to make your way to, presumably, a toaster, without touching the floor for too long.  The longer you are on the floor, the less edible you become until you finally lose the level.The mechanics are tough to get used to, even more menacing than Octodad.  Each side of the toast is assigned a key and you have to decide which corner is your pivot point and move the mouse.  You have a "grip meter" for moving up surfaces, like climbing the refrigerator or the cabinets, so this adds an extra, "time sensitive" element to it.Overall, I really have liked it so far.  Seems like it will provide a lot of very fun and challenging play.  If you want to see the gameplay, I did make a video:


YouTube™ Video: I Am Bread - Part 1 

			Views: 367		

			I am a slice of bread who dreams of some day becoming toast.

content:
Posted: October 7, 2016
												We were all told not to play with our food.  Now, our food plays... with us.Straight out, it's clear this is not a game for everyone.  Expecting a silly Bread 'Simulator' Youtube-sensation smash-em-up?  Look elsewhere.  I AM BREAD needs *surprising* amounts of skill and puzzle solving.  Surprising unless you've played Surgeon Simulator, Bossa's previous game, which likewise required you to train your brain to learn what keys WON'T hurl spoons and scalpels all over the theatre.  This'll sound scathing but some reviewers prefer the Bagel Racing because it's a lot more straight forward and not at all punishing.  If you're interested enough to read this, you'll laugh plenty while you play, yet I AM BREAD will make you feel like your mild-mannered alter-ego has been bashed around the head with a baguette.Story Mode: Yes, story mode about living bread.  The other modes are a very fun distraction but Story Mode hooked me in.  It's a surgeon simulator prequel!  As surreal and daft as that is, it works. You're taken on an adventure and the world really does become all about one thing: You aren't just bread; you must become TOAST.  You play through as a loaf possessed with life, each slice seeking any and all ways to become everyone's favourite morning accompaniment.  Story Mode takes place over the course of a week.  One of the joys is how the mission at hand engages you completely, and before long the escalating impact of your toasty obsession becomes deadly clear.  This loaf will stop at nothing, slowly pushing its owner into a frenzy while the world (or his therapist and security guards, at least) thinks him insane. Controls: You have complete control of every corner and every movement of your wholesome slice, and you will have to learn how not just to grip, but how to flip, how to leap, how to swing and hurl things about to get through the levels.  The levels aren't just kitchens and lounges and petrol stations, because there is an increasing requirement to learn what you've tried out in previous levels to get through the next.  This is one thing that makes I AM BREAD much more of a game than I think a lot of players give it credit for.  It takes timing and practice and a lot of patience - with yourself more than anything!! You'll totally flop on some key manoeuvre and curse your aching fingers, but you'll try again and figure it out.  The only difference between limping across a kitchen surface or crawling painfully up the side of a bin, and flipping across car bonnets or leaping across chasms and flipping gracefully over petrol station shelving, is YOU. Levels: Over the course of a week, you'll have to find heat sources, of which there are a few even in the same level, while avoiding anything that'll render you inedible.  Later you'll have to be a bit more creative (and destructive?) in your mission to toast yourself.  It requires level exploration until you spot something, it clicks, or you have that "I wonder if..." moment.  The levels are littered with everyday objects and I adored how everything seemed to move right, from bin lids to swinging petrol station signs, to individual piles of books and rolling gas tanks.  Some things break physics conveniently without going anywhere near the stupidity of something like goat simulator - switches move easily at a stroke, bread is surprisingly strong enough to hurl bricks at cars, and lighters will flick just by touching them.  These breaks are convenient and welcome!  If things get too difficult too often, you are offered a way to become edible no matter what you land on, but I recommend avoiding this.  Staying edible is half the game!Other Modes: Thanks to Bossa's intent on providing banquets rather than just the one offering (surgeon simulator had several modes by the time they were done), the other modes add content to this game each with its own brilliant twist.  Bagel Racing is easy to get to grips with, though I did initially expect to race other bagels and multiplayer bagels would have been fantastic.  Starch Wars is pretty epic in which you'll take on an evil ironing board and its Rye Fighters.  Rampage puts you in control of a very angry baguette intent on smashing everything, swinging itself about like a baseball bat.  Cheese hunt sees you take on a quest for several pieces of cheese in a room as a piece of Rye, but isn't so interesting.  Zero-G is surprisingly addictive and very nicely done.  I haven't completed the Team Fortress mode but its a quirky version of the same thing and looks a lot of fun as you interact with familiar objects and weapons from comatose Heavy Weapons Guy's world.It's not a long game, over with in a couple of evenings or maybe 4-6 hours (depending on what you do with the other modes).  It's very silly, great to play with mates or family around, it's got a nice dark glint in its eye, it's easy to play and difficult to master, but your patience and determination will be rewarded.  Remember this is a game in a true sense and you'll be ready - YOU WILL BE TOAST.  I am a fan.  If you've even read this far, just get it on offer and have a great time.No spoilers intended here but my girlfriend was absorbed in this game's story and right at the end just asked one question: "Why doesn't Mr. Murton just make his bread into toast?  Then everyone would be happy."  Why didn't you just, Mr. Murton?

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 20, 2015
												Well as of writing this review I've played it less than an hour and to be honest I didn't acomplish much. While this game is a fun look at physics, as a game it lacks some of the more satisfying things we've come to love.I consider this to be much more of a test of frustration than anything. The controls are stiff and very hard to use. I've seen people complain about how hard it is with the mouse and keyboard so I opted to use the controller instead, and its still way too difficult for the average person to grasp. It demands motions that your brain isn't familiar with making and gives you very little time to work with it.Overall it's still a good game, and I plan on dedicating more time to it later, but its just not really fun to play right now.Pros:- The graphics are fun, and the music is nice to play to.- It seems like with a little work it COULD be fun to play.- As a physics game it is very solid.Cons:- The controls are awful. And when I say awful, I mean they are just not intuitive. It seems like there could easily be a better way to work them but they have elected to go with the most difficult non-intuitive choice possible. The only way it could get harder is if you had to order the bread around with your voice.- The game timer and edibility meter sucks. When you fall on the floor you have mere moments to react before you lose. And I understand "Who wants to eat dirty bread?" But it wouldn't be so bad if the controls weren't such crap to begin with.- It seems like the difficulty isn't in the placement of obstacles or even the fact that if you get too dirty you are trash, but rather it seems that they have chosen to make the controls as difficult to use as a way to make it a more difficult game, and that takes the competitiveness and fun right out of it. If they made the game's controls a whole lot easier to use and instead ramped up the difficulty with obstacles it would be a more successful game in my opinion. Instead it feels like lazy development.- You are going to get frustrated, and I mean at epic levels. Once you realize that the reason you cant get somewhere easily isnt because its a difficult game but that moving the bread around sucks horribly you will want to throw your controller out the window.All in all, I am still recommending this game for two reasons.1. Some people like these really difficult games and they do have a place in the market, and the game isn't terrible. I imagine if i wanted to dedicate like 12 hours just to learning the controls I could probably master it. The problem with this as I see it is I'm not learning to fly an airplane or drive a car here. I'm playing a video game. When a normal game could be finished in 12 hours and I'm still learning how to move a piece of bread around that might be a problem, but I digress.2. There is a game somewhere in here if I can find it, if I find more patience. With enough time I could master this and that is true of any strategy based game but is this one of those games?I wonder if your average person would waste the time needed to get good at this game or just uninstall it and chalk up the wasted money?I don't think unless you are a true fan of torture this game is worth full price, however if its on sale at least 50% it's worth a try.

content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												I loved this game, then it was fully released.   I got this game early on in developement and throughout it being in early access I have extremely enjoyed playing the game. After exstensive amounts of new content being added I did feel it was close to full release as long as the dogey controller support was fixed. The day it was released I turned on my computer (which during early access easily handled I Am Bread with medium graphics settings) and played the new level in story mode. The framerate dropped to below 30 fps and strobe lighting effects kicked in. It was basically un playable. To see whether or not it was that level I tried a different level, same results. After turning my graphics to low and shadowing off, the strobe lighting stopped but the framerate was still awfull and the game looked ugly. Same thing with the other modes to. It was impossible for me to actually make progress in the new level which seemed awesome. This wasn't because of bad playing skills, I had beaten every level in story mode up to the final release. Overall I think it just kneads a patch to fix this and the controller support.   Other than that, I would deffinately reccomend this. The devs did a great job on it and they might have upped the graphics and my computer couldn't handle it. If you have a beefy computer and think it can handle this game, get it.

												Dumb Part : You look at the game.See the name.You understand that it is Dumb.You go to the store page.See the reviews , Look at the Pictures and Videos.The you buy it.Gj Bossa.Serious : Well this game is amazing , very fun and Cool.With 6 Game modes , and 4 types of different Breads, Amazing soundtrack (Which is included For Free at the game files) , and a unique Gameplay.I have played the early access version for hours.But when I played the Full game i Noticed some Things and problems that the game has and Some were More likely In the Early access Version.For Example:1.The levels were Harder In the Early access (Specially the First level) , for exaple they changed  the toaster in the kitchen , Which in the early access was a typical toaster with 2 Holes Since they were SO Small , you would get mad till you can fit your self in it. But they changed it to a big opened toaster which is easy to get in .2. When you started the early access version there was a menu which you could choose what resolution and graphic quality you want but now i just cant find anything to change my graphics. Since my Laptop isnt very strong i have to run the game at it's "Safe mode" which surprisingly still has good graphics but the Lights and the Textures of the floor and other things just flash and give you a Headache.Now lets go to the good things about the Full version : 1. The HUD is a LOT better in the full version , with some Special effects and beeing Much Colorful.2. Full Story Mode !!!3. Inhanced Rampage mode. Rampage mode is The BEST part of the game in my idea. It was Great back then , And it is Still GREAT now. The improvement that they made is that They Re-Designed the maps Only for the Rampage mode. And There is a lot of BANG and BOOM sound right now because everything breaks in RAMPAGE MODE!!!!4. Something taht i like about the Full Version is that the Store page Has improved a lot !!! I like it This way !5. And finally Achievments and Trading cards which The Early access didnt have those.Thats all i can say about the game.Its fun , Amazing , And pretty Challenging.I love the Game.It is Definitely worth buying it.8.5 / 10Gj Bossa , Again.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								Having completed the game (as much of it as there is) I can't wholly recommend it. It's definitely a nice curiosity, and it has some entertainment value - But it can also be very frustrating due to the unpredictable nature of the physics.Obviously, getting used to it you'll get better at manoeuvering yourself around the environments, you'll still have difficulty executing an exact plan and making any fine adjustments. It's hard to imagine how they might improve the control system for mouse and keyboard, but one remains hopeful.The concept remains quite funny, and the bolt-on story serves to amuse as you progress, as well as give reason to the increasingly elaborate household gauntlets of various unpleasant substances strewn across your path.In short, as the novelty goes I think I would recommend the game - However from a purely critical perspective of enjoying the game itself and the content that exists as of yet, I would say go for it if you're interested, but only cautiously.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								Don't actually spend money on this game. It's novel for about 15 minutes and then it's just infuriating.EDIT:I spent $10 on this game. I usually am a fan of games that are hard even if they're a bit tedious. I enjoyed VVVVVV and Papers,Please. The problem with this game is that it's hard just for the sake of being hard. Even ignoring the less-than-ideal physics on account of it being early access. The game loses it's appeal quickly and has essentially no replay value. The controls are unessecarily complicated and there's not even any satisfaction in completing a level, because the next one is just as infuriating. It's like paying money for QWOP. If I could have gotten it for $1.99, the 15 minutes of entertainment struggling might have been worth it. But it wasn't worth $10.

content:
Posted: December 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								Video Review: 


YouTube™ Video: I Am Bread Gameplay : Pt1. It's Dough-licious 

			Views: 218		

			Brandon Dayton review and gameplay of I am Bread by Bossa Studios. Posted with permission on indiegamebundles.com. I am not actually bread. Though now I kind of wish I was. Regret cuts like a knife.		

Full text w/ photos: http://www.indiegamebundles.com/review-i-am-bread/Simulator games are in their hayday to be sure. There’s a simulator for everything you ever wanted to be, as well as games for a couple things you had no idea you wanted to be. I Am Bread has become the supreme frontrunner of the latter category in my book. The story is hysterical, told via psychiatrist statements about a man with rooms in his house being destroyed, and swearing that bread can move. The music is spot on, and the controls can take a lot of getting used to, but are completely fair. Made by Bossa Studios, it’s not a far throw from Surgeon Simulator, except that it features a wonderfully huge open world to explore, rather than just some dude’s chest cavity. You’ve been a goat, a deer, a gorilla, a farmer, a prisoner, a spaceman, and a rock. Now it’s finally time to pinch your inner loaf… Or something like that. Lets take a closer look at I Am Bread.The first thing you’ll probably notice when you get into the game is the strange controls. Q,W,E,R (Or LT/LB RT/LB) are each assigned to a corner of your slice, pressing that button will cause the bread to grab, then you can fling yourself around using your mouse or control stick.  It sounds so simple, but much pain went into perfecting its execution… I’d say it was almost an hour before I became the ninja-bread man I never knew I longed to be. Once you finally stop nudging your bread along like Granny Gumgums, the music starts to click. It’s jazzy and quick and it makes my wall-crawling bread feel like he’s truly on the most dramatic adventure of his life. Hell, it probably is. It’s just a slice of bread after all.Once you’ve mastered your abilities, you must complete the mission of getting toasted. Some lowly peons will tell you to use a toaster. Poppycock! I say find the nearest blow-dryer and just do what comes most natural. You also must stay off the floor, and away from gross stuff like trash and dishwater, as it will deplete your edibility bar. Once bread is no longer edible, it’s dead. Dead bread. The world is amazingly interactive. Almost everything can be broken or flung across the room via wonky physics, with delightful results! There is only one puzzle, “How can I become toast?”, but the answers are multiple, and as creative as you care to make them.Now the ugly. The game does crash quite a bit… Which made recording at any length a bit frustrating. The controls are strange, but it’s likely on purpose, to increase the wackiness. That doesn’t do much for the extreme difficulty spike between the first level and the second, but there is time to adjust that as well. I also have to point out that the hardest part is wiggling yourself into the toaster. It caused me SO much heartache… You finally get to the toaster, only to discover that the real struggle has just begun. Overall though, I had a lot of fun with this game, and will likely return to it in the future. The environments are varied, and the freedom to solve a puzzle by riding on a rocket or skateboard, or simply scooting along the rug in a pot amuses me to no end.Summary: A zany bread-simulator game with an open world and loads of freedom.Final Score: 7/10 for gameplay, physics, and replayability. 9/10 with smaller difficulty curve.

content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
												It's Qwop. In 3d. With bread. I can't be arsed to finish the ♥♥♥♥ing thing so I have no idea whether the theme of bread will make sense at the end or if it's just for the lulz so random factor.Fact is it could be a lot of fun. It certainly looks fun anyway. When it works, it is fun. But the camera is atrocious, and since your bread rotate based on where the camera stands all it takes is making a few steps of progress for whatever angle you had on your bread to change and thus having to do a frustrating balancing act with both joystiq when all it would take to make the game actually playable would be to have the camera fixed. The camera doesn't move unless you move it.That's all it would take to make the game three times more enjoyable. It's that one tiny little thing that makes the game pretty much unbearable. Perhaps that's the point, it's cleverly designed to be just at the frontier between fun and complete garbage.Whatever the case, wait for a sale. Don't pay full price. It's not worth it.

												Easily one of the worst games i have ever played it has given me new found respect for youtubers like pewdiepie who can manage to entertain people while playing this garbage. If I can run most of todays top role playing games with little lag then i believe the problem is with this game in itself. I'm tapped out at three hours with this game. I never expected it to be good but I thought it would be a good laugh with a few friends buts its not. Early Access Review
								This game is amazing! Overall, I give it two crumbs up! Anyone with taste and the ability to get themself out of a jam in a jiffy should buy this game.At first, your spirits may go flat, unleavened, as you fail to grain control of your floppy, four cornered friend. But soon, you realize that, after a flour or two of playing, this game is everything that you could possibly imagine. I mean, you're a freaking slice of bread. It is classified as one of the main food groups!This game promotes a healthy lifestyle. Nothing is healthier than rolling, tripping, and flipping around your house (who needs feet anyways?) as you coat your body in various condiments, all towards the ultimate goal of making yourself  attractive... er... tasty... for that special someone... er..... crazy man who knows you're destroying his home.

content:
Posted: August 26, 2016
												I do kind of wish there was a "Neutral" option for this review.This game falls under the category of games such as Goat Simulator that expects you to find it funny on premise alone, and sadly it's one joke that lands for very few and even if it does land for you it's unlikely you'll find it funny for several hours.So... Why is this a recommendation?-Unlike Goat Simulator, there isn't a grand total of one joke per level. It's ridiculous how many puns are packed into the game and some of the more subtle ones actually made me chuckle. There are no shortage of bread puns in this game.-This game succeeds in the same way Surgeon Simulator succeeded- It actually has merit above just being a game with bad controls. Both this and Surgeon Sim are games with actual learning curves and the potential of mastery- Games where you can actually get better and better at them and earn your A++ rank.-Actually really, really hard. I'm not even joking, this game is pretty tough especially if you want high rankings.-Surprisingly open levels. Your goal is to become toast, but there are many different ways to do that- Making your way to a toaster is one, but you could also toast yourself inside an oven or on a BBQ. How you get to something that can make you into toast is also completely up to you, as long as it doesn't consist of crawling along dirty surfaces such as the floor- But even then, skilful play can get you across the floor with minimal damage, too.But there's a lot of things that drag this game down, too, unfortunately.-Like Surgeon Simulator's A&E Edition it outstays its welcome. The campaign mode is at a pretty good length, but if you want 100% completion in this game it will be an incredibly painful and boring experience. They mix it up with different kinds of bread but it isn't really different enough to work particularly well. Especially with all the extra stuff they've added through updates. It's very unlikely you'll actually have the interest to play every extra level at least once.-The controls are actually TOO bad. Surgeon Sim is a game that appears to have bad controls to the uninitiated, but all you need to do is actually learn the controls and the controls will no longer be an obstacle to your play. I Am Bread, on the other hand, doesn't appear to have that quality- No matter how good you get the game's physics engine will still screw you over at times because your very movement is dependent on the game's physics engine. This may have been because of the fact I didn't use a controller but I still feel like even movement felt more difficult than it needed to be.-Once again, it may be because I didn't use a controller, but those zero-gravity levels... UGH.-There didn't appear to be any secrets or secret levels like there were in Surgeon Simulator. Surgeon Sim had this titanic number of easter eggs and so on that were pieced together in order to discover an amazing secret level- I Am Bread doesn't have anything like that.Overall I Am Bread is IMO not as good as Surgeon Simulator was. It still manages to do what games of its type consistently fail to do but it's a downgrade to what Surgeon Sim was. It's not exactly a game I can muster up a "Not Recommended" rating for because it does have merit especially if this kind of game is what you're looking for, but I'd still recommend you pick up Surgeon Sim instead of this.

There is a flash game called "The World's Hardest Game" as we all know but it's name should be changed to "The World's Second Hardest Game" and this game should be changed to "The Worlds Hardest Game" instead. Even with a remote it is still excrutiatingly hard. You can tell because a youtuber who everyone knows about called Markiplier played this game and he smashed his remote to bits in anger and he openly admitted that he could not play this game and it has made him "more angry than he has ever been in his entire life". Honestly I do not blame him.So if you are thinking about buying this game; don't bother. It's a complete waste of time and money and YES I have tried it myself and I had to get a refund because I could not do it. I regret buying this game and I don't even know why I got it in the first place. It's that bad. :(

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								Just learned that if you cover yourself with jam, you can rest on walls. This solves my main problem with the game.This makes the game far less irritating. It's still challenging, if you make a wrong move, you'll end up on the ground and become inedible.I find bread with jam far more enjoyable. I think they should make that feature more obvious.--------It looks like fun, but it gets pretty tedious. Many indie games use poor controls as a humourous gameplay mechanic, eg Octodad. But here it is an exercise in frustration. This is mainly due to the Grip meter. You can only hold on to things for a certain amount of time, so if you're not quick enough you'll have to do the same thing over and over and over.While Octodads challenge comes from the poor controls, the challenge here comes from the timer. This makes the game irritating instead of humourous.Maybe they'll remove the "timer" based challenge to something more substantial. But until that happens I wouldn't recommend this game.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2016
												Yet another "hilariously" bad game that embraces its own awfulness. The challenge of the game lies solely in fighting the God-awful controls. That said, the concept behind the game is solid; you're a piece of bread trying to get from point A to point B while navigating the environment without touching the floor. It could have been a surprisingly fun title if the the develepor wasn't trying so hard to capture lightning in a bottle again as they did with the equally atrocious, and undeservedly popular, Surgeon Simulator 2013. I would seek a refund if I hadn't recieved my copy from a Humble Bundle. 1/10, don't waste your time with this title even if somebody offers you a free copy.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is infuriatingly hard.The first hour, I didn't really do anything. I couldn't figure out the controls, so I just kindof loafed around.Eventually, I finally figured out how to tip myself over, and subsequently how to toss myself around.My first goal: The counter. I prepared myself to swing right over there.Bready, Set, Dough!Whoops, undershot it by the entire distance and fell on the floor.After a while, I finally got the hang of it.Okay, tip off the loaf, roll into this jar. Spread jam all over myself. Now, fling into the backboard of this chair, and tip it over to the counter. Roll up the side. YES! I made it to the counter! Now I just- Oh dough, ants.I'm starting to think I'll never be toast.I am bread, and I may always be bread.

												I've never been happier than I was when I started being bread. Life is so simple when you're bread. There's nothing to worry about, you don't need a job or a wife, people don't put pressure on a baguette to be a crispbread, you don't need to pretend to be something you're not. You can just sit on the kitchen counter and look out upon the vast view of your kitchen dominion, or huddle up on a stormy night in the bread bin with all your bread kin.I would recommend becoming bread to all my friends.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 5, 2015
												The fun factor is the sole reason why I bought this game. My initial expectation with simulator games is always on the positive note. I am a bread and I need to go to the toaster to toast myself. It took me quite a few minutes to come up with a faster way of defying gravity using the four controls: *ehem* swing mechanism *ehem*. But alas, I got to the toaster and it took me 30 minutes of hell trying to fit myself (as a bread) inside that freaking toaster. I gave up, and thought maybe I should have covered myself with butter first? Seemingly, impatience has overpowered the potential of this game to be fun. Maybe in the future I'll try again. But I still need to collect and calm myself.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 5, 2015
												Great idea, horrible execution.Controls are cool, but just too random. And this isn't the funny awkward kind of random, but the annoying "What the hell is it doing" kind. I try to move past things and either my bread humps the butter or flings itself right off the table. Like, controlled movement isn't possible at all.Then, when my bread finally humped its way through the dangers of the kitchen to the toaster... its dream was shattered by the seemingly impossible task of getting into the damn thing. Climbing up wasn't enough. Humping to eventually slide in didn't work either. (Poor bread would be a horrible lover.) The amazing stunt of climbing to the bottom of the cupboard above the toaster and falling right ontop of it failed as well. So, after a good hour of trying, I gave up.Beside that, the camera was constantly moving to the most annoying positions. It got stuck at objects, behind walls or zoomed extremely close. And the longer I played, the worse got the lag. At the beginning, there wasn't any lag at all. As expected, considering my hardware. But for some reason it started lagging and getting worse over time.Despite the humping bread, which gave me a good laugh, I consider this a waste of time and money.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 10, 2015
												I never knew how terrifying and stressful can floors be before playing this game. I might even reconsider leaving dirty dishes on my table because that could mean ants, and ants are evil. And don't even let me start on sinks full of water. So many thimgs which stand between an adventurous loaf of bread and the crunchy victory. I've only played the game with a controller, so I can't judge how well it can be controlled with a keyboard. However, the controls were okay for me. Stressful, maddening, which-corner-of-the-bread-is-this line of thought all the time, but okay.It's true it might get boring after a while, but I developed a masochistic instinct which keeps whispering in my head "Go try if your bread wall climbing skills improved!". So yeah, it drags you back. Overall, recommended. It's a simulator that gives you something to think about. Like, feeling guilty about the bread you consumed without toasting it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is, without a doubt, the best bread simulator I've ever played. For years now, I have found games lacking. "If only I could be bread in this game," I thought, "Everything would be so much better."I've finally gotten my wish with I Am Bread. The storyline is wonderful and cute. I am deeply moved by the desire of the bread to get toasted and the lengths it goes to. The level design is fun and creative, and I look forward to them adding more, as there are only four levels right now.There are a few bugs, of course, as it's currently in early access, but nothing major.I visited my family recently, and my little sister (10), my little brother (14), my dad, and my fiancé all saw me playing, and wanted a go, and thought it was amazing!I do wish there were an endless play mode, where you could explore the whole house, or perhaps a mode with no grip limit so I could get to know the levels.Keep up the amazing work, Dev team, and I look forward to more.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
												The controls in this game are atrocious. Even with my hours of experience, even with my 100% completion, I will never like the controls of this game. That said, eventually you pick up tricks to make movement easier and more tolerable, and honestly that makes the game fun for me. But the controls at first will be a major negative for a lot of people. Beyond that, the premise is humorous, there's actually somewhat of a plot, and the levels are varied pretty well. I'd recommend this game for some silly fun, but I don't expect anyone to stick with it as long as I did.

												and your goal, is to be Toast. You, a single slice, of soft white bread, wishes to adventure away from the loaf and find a source of heat. If you are strong, and wise, you will find a path that allows you to find your goal before being covered in filth. If one becomes covered by the darkness of sins that cover the lands between your home and your destination then you will become trapped and unable to continue your quest. Although, if you are able to travel the rough lands and find the holy lands of warmth, you must be able to perfectly bask in the warmth to allow yourself to become what you were born to be. . . TOAST. . . . Just don't burn yourself, no one likes to eat charcoal.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								“Abandon all hope, ye who enter here.”The controls, camera, and movement are all tied together and become an exercise in frustration. My rage over this, if its energy harnessed, could easily power the world three fold – but I digress. Objects here and elsewhere, fall broken into pieces as soon as you touch them (sometimes even if you don't), and everything else will move around, but never in a way that's useful. You'll begin by planning your route, being extra careful and resetting frequently to achieve perfection. This optimism will not last. After the fatigue sets in and your initial happiness turns into bile, you'll desperately try to haul your disgusting slice as far as the game will allow. Your sighs, lamentations and loud wailings will resound through the starless air. And when the game awards all your pain and suffering with a D grade, you will not feel shame, but elation, for the struggle as finally come to an end. An end that is short lived, as it serves only to reveal to you the next circle of hell. But, like every masochistic addict, you will not cowardly make the great refusal. You must go deeper into greater pain, for necessity brings you here, not pleasure. And when you emerge from your room to return to the bright world, without care of having any rest, you can hold your head up high and know that you could face no greater test. You are bread.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 9, 2015
Early Access Review
Components+ Graphically, I AM BREAD gets it right, if it were extremely realistic, the game wouldn’t be as humorous and enjoyable, as when things get realistic, it feels to grown up and focused rather than fun and enjoyable. And I AM BREAD is all about enjoying being a slice of bread with a mission of getting toasted. Although the levels of I AM BREAD is very well designed, easy to distinguish which area is dirty and which is clean, and the effect it has on your bread as it comes in contact with certain substances.+ Gameplay is rather self explanatory, four keys for each limb and an extra button for each to lock the limb, and with the compatibility of the Xbox Controller, it makes it easier to control as well. The developers do a great job on getting reactions from players, because accidents always happen, the controls can be confusing when under pressure, thus panic and overwhelming emotions, all of which make the experience enjoyable.+- Gamemode is very simple, just get toasted, but I think they could expand on this like Goat Simulator did, which was make it an MMO, allowing for more interaction with other players. I am guessing they could make I AM BREAD larger with multiplayer modes, who could get toasted quicker or something like that, you can challenge your friends on a level at the same time. Because a singular game mode will be easy to get bored of, adding more, or specifically multiplayer, it would probably benefit the game largely.+ The amount of room you have to be your slice of bread is good factor. Because you have multiple ways and approaches to getting toasted and what to slather yourself with before you do. Because the toy is only as good as the room you play it in.+ And I think with the continuous involvement of the I AM BREAD community, they will continue to improve, and maybe with the addition of the Steam Workshop which could alter your type of bread, or add more levels to play, I AM BREAD will be a long lasting game.OverallI AM BREAD is without a doubt a very fun simulator game, it has never been done before and that is what gamers like to see, something unique and amazing. People might’ve thought of making a simulator for ridiculous things but never thought they will pull it off so they kept to the cliché simulators, which are vehicles.But I AM BREAD has been pulled off spectacularly well; it is most definitely fun experience, playing as bread with the mission of getting toasted. The idea was ridiculous but the developers made it happen. It’s an ambitious and successful idea, which deserves all the support it gets. Well worth the price and the experience. I suggest this game to simulator lovers and people who just like to play ridiculous yet great games (Goat Sim | BroForce).

								Honestly, there aren't words to describe this game. It's not good, but it isn't bad either. It's just so... it's just... it's... The only word I have ever been able to use to describe this game or EVER will be able to use to describe this game is... BREAD. Just BREAD. I didn't hate it. I sort of enjoyed it. Wait, does screaming, "GET IN THE @#%$ TOASTER!!!!" at my computer qualify as enjoying something? I dunno. Just, whatever you do, PLEASE don't play this with a keyboard. For your sake. I'm serious. If you plan on buying this game and you don't have a controller, get one. Seriously. Now.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2015
												For a game that a first glance seems like some LOLSOFUNNEHXD youtuber bait, it's actually quite fun and hasn't gone stale just yet.EDIT: Now that the full release has came out, I wouldn't reccomend this game anymore (at least for people like me). Ironically enough, a game about bread cannot run decently on a (metaphorical) toaster like the pre-release could. The game suffers horrible framerate drops, and the lighting flickers on and off like crazy with gif recording enabled. In the beta, an option came up on launch to choose your graphics settings and you could set it to a max performace setting. Not only are similar options unavailable, but the game runs like crap on the lowest setting I could get it to. It really sucks that I can't bearably run this game anymore, especially since there seems to be a lot of new cool and fun content.AND ANOTHER EDIT: It works relatively fine on toasters now. Gif recording still causes some weird flickering with the lighting, dough.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 7, 2015
												I love games like this, they're goofy, fun, and challenging. There are people who may not consider this as a true "game," but the point of games like these is that they break the mould, and discover new ways to entertain. Also, doesn't usually fail in making you laugh in the end.Upon starting up the game, I was using a keyboard. Yes, it is difficult, but just like with any game, you learn how it works. It took me a hilarious hour to finish the tutorial. I don't regret it. Went into free roam next to get a better handle on controls, check out the environment. Being each type of bread can present its own difficulties surprisingly. I did connect one of my controllers up to play this, and it is much easier. Although, if you just set your "grips" to comfortable keys close together, it shouldn't be much of a problem to use a keyboard. Going through the game, there are a lot of little things to find, and interact with. At the end of one game session, all that I could see of my little toast was chips, eggs, and jam/jelly sitting in a pile of mass destruction. You can try to skateboard, but I seem to fail that, and just send myself flying. Curiosity sent me into a garbage can. All in all, this is a game you'd love if you like challenging physics, comedy, bread, and a bit of mini sandbox exploration.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												This game is very unique, fun, and challenging! It's like the Goat Simulator of bread. If you enjoy Goat Simulator, or games where you can mess around in general, or just want to pass time, this is for you! This is one of the best gaming experiences I've ever been through. And what's better is you can free roam around the map after finishing it in the story! I reccommend playing this game with an XBox 360/One or PS3/PS4 controller. I use the XBox 360 controller with this, and I cannot emphasize enough that it makes the gameplay a LOT more easy. The keyboard is very well useable for gameplay, but controllers are best IMO.I really feel that this game is something that I could play for hours on end and not get bored. I just played it for 70 mins before deciding to write a review, and haven't found anything I don't like about it yet. The gameplay is very straight forward and easy to figure out. And if you're worried about forgetting controls - fear not! it displays the buttons you can press on the corners of the bread as you play.I highly reccomend this game. Good job, Bossa.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								So imagine that Mount Your Friends got an extra dimension and became less suggestive, open world, and also bread. You play a slice of bread and your objective is to become toast. You have an edibility bar that is effectively your health. The floor and other dirty places will lower that and once it hits 0 you fail the level. You have no time limit, but if you take too long, you get a worse rating. I finished the first level three times. I got E, D, and C. The next level didn’t unlock till I got a C. Controls were frustrating at first and after an hour of play.... were still rather frustrating. That said there are two possible schemes of control: mouse/keyboard and controller. They both will give you a different level of control. You have 4 buttons corresponding to the corners of the bread slice you control. Pressing a button will cause that corner to stick to the environment. You then can use the mouse or analog stick to move yourself. With a mouse you have far more force behind your movements. With an analog stick, it feels like the bread is struggling to move. You also have a limited amount of time for consecutive grip.Despite the odd feel of the controls, the game has some fun moments. There is something special about sliding across the wall like a piece of spider-bread. The feeling of mastering the controls is a rewarding experience if nothing else. It’s an interesting and unique game that I expect to become into something more interesting, if Surgeon Simulator is an example.In conclusion: Wonky controls, not much content, but an early access game that’s been out for about a week or so. If you don’t buy now but are still interested, keep an eye on its development to see what comes of it.
